fields.title: Juany Torres
fields.statement:
Hey Stanford! 
I am **Juany Torres**, and I am at your service. 


Endorsed by:
------------

-**SOCC- Students of Color Coalition** 
-**Women's Coalition**
-**Queer Rights Coalition**
-**Colleges Against Cancer Coalition**


I am currently running to be YOUR Stanford ASSU Senator for the 2010-2011 school year and would love and appreciate your support during my campaign, and hopefully, term as ASSU Senator.


So, why should you elect me as your ASSU Senator?
 
What distinguishes me from the other candidates…**Experience**. 

As a freshman with an incredible amount of love for Stanford University, I have served as: 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
*ASSU Senate Associate

*Faisan’s dorm president

*HAAS Center Frosh Service Ambassador

*Dance Marathon Dorm Captain

*Member of Stanford 20th Annual Raza Day planning Committee 

*Relay for Life Team Captain

As a dedicated ASSU Senate Associate this year, I was given the opportunity to work with the current ASSU Senators and grasp a clear understanding of what goes on with our Senate. I learned a lot of what the duties of senators are and the way the Senate works. This knowledge and experience will help me be an effective and productive ASSU Senator if elected into office with YOUR support. 

Many students feel as if the ASSU Senate has not adequately served as a clear and direct representation of the student body’s needs, and with my experience as a Senate Associate, I have learned from the mistakes and flaws of the current ASSU and am determined to  change that. I want to be YOUR advocate; I want to represent YOUR voice.

So why am I running? 
--------------------
Our years at the Farm are going by way too quickly, and I want to create an ASSU that works hard to make them the most enjoyable, productive, and amazing years you have ever experienced. I want to make sure that our ASSU emphasizes collaboration and communication between the student body and the Senate because if we want the ASSU to be as effective as possible, we need everyone’s input! 


With YOUR vote, I will advocate for:
------------------------------------

**Free Speech**
As an ASSU Senator, I will work on legislation to codify your rights to free speech and ensure that Stanford University protects and values what the students have to say. Your voice is important and should be allowed to be expressed in every way possible as long as it is not in violation of the free speech of others.

**An end to Acts of Intolerance**
Even at Stanford, they unfortunately still exist. Lack of awareness for these acts of injustice is a huge reason why they have not been put a stop to. Through different info sessions, a blog, and even performances by some of our most amazing student groups, I hope to promote awareness for the different experiences students have had with acts of intolerance. As your ASSU Senator, I also plan to reform the Acts of Intolerance Protocol, making it easier for students to report acts of intolerance that they have witnessed and/or been victims of.  The current Acts of Intolerance Protocol is lengthy and a very slow process, discouraging many victims of harassment, especially members of the Queer community, women, and minorities, to speak up for their student and human rights. I will work endlessly to ensure that every student is treated with the respect that he/she deserves, making Stanford University a safe and open campus for all. 

**Diversity**
Stanford University is one of the most diverse campuses in the world, and as such, it is important to value and celebrate our many cultures, ideas, and beliefs. By working with the Faculty Senate, the ASSU Executive team, and my fellow ASSU Senators, we can emphasize the need for faculty and grad student diversity. It is as important to have professors that represent all ideas and beliefs as it is to have a great variety of cultures represented through our student body. It is also crucial to make sure that students of all ethnicities and sexual orientation have a Stanford that ensures safe and open spaces. If we do not protect our amazing array of students, we will begin to lose the beautiful diversity that Stanford University is so well known and treasured for. 

**Student Groups**
There are over 600 student groups at Stanford University! 600! I strongly believe that a huge part of what makes Stanford the best school on this planet is the amazing community that our student groups form part of. It is extremely important for student groups to receive the support of their ASSU Senate, and therefore I intend to make sure that our student groups are included in the decisions the Senate makes by keeping in constant communication with them and ensuring that they are “in the loop” of things. I want to include the student groups from day one, communicating information as well as their opinion and ideas and taking into consideration the many effects that my decision as a Senator will have on VSOs. 

**Transparency**
Transparency lacked this year, seeing that even the minutes failed to be posted after every meeting, and I will make sure to change that next year, making sure that the student body knows what is going on with their Senate through weekly updates, videos, and segments in the Stanford Daily.  Every decision will be made open to the public, and there will be no behind the scenes actions that can negatively affect the student body and VSOs. 

**Appropriations reform**
Appropriations reform is definitely a priority in my agenda. As a Senator, I will reform the special fees process, making it a more equal and easier method of receiving funds. I will include VSO student group FOs in the process and take into consideration their concerns and suggestions on how to allocate funds in the most efficient way possible. Each community center serves as a home away from home to many of our students, and it is the Senate’s responsibility to protect and continue to invest in their preservation. 


**I want to be YOUR ASSU Senator! I want you to believe in my ability to serve as your advocate! I want to work together and change the way the ASSU has worked before! ** 

**I want, with your vote, to ensure YOUR voice is heard!**

Take my word for it…IT’S JUANY T. GUARANTEED! 
---------------------------------------------



Feel free to join my facebook group:
 
[<http://www.facebook.com/group.php?v=info&ref=mf&gid=106890856010770>]

or my personal facebook:

[<http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?ref=profile&id=100000026728017>]

I will be more than happy to answer any and all questions you might have!


**THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR TIME AND SUPPORT!**

fields.title: Percia Safar
fields.statement:
As an Undergraduate Senator, Percia will:

**Ethics**

    * Diminish stipends for elected members of the ASSU (No Double Standards!)
    * Increase scrutiny of discretionary funds
    * Advertise meeting agendas in advance and publish minutes regularly

**Funding**

    * Publicize funding guidelines and ensure transparency
    * Increase Office Hours/FO Workshops held by the Appropriations Committee
    * Incorporate VSO feedback via quarterly surveys

**Academics**

    * Mandate greater Freshman Advisor accountability through evaluations
    * Advertise the Book Exchange and efforts to cut book costss
    * Make library study rooms reservable online like Old Union

**Student Life**

    * Reduce free speech restrictions throughout campus
    * Promote the use of study spaces in Old Union and the Niterys
    * Support more speakers, concerts, and social events

fields.title: Khaled "Shawi" Alshawi
fields.statement:
Here are reasons why you should vote for Khaled 'SHAWI' Alshawi to be an Undergraduate Senator:

- He served as the dorm president of the largest residence on campus (Roble) for the first half of the year and is an ASSU Senate Associate, allowing him to identify the issues that this campus faces. He has the commitment and passion, but needs the authority from YOU.

AND

- He knows his stuff! Going to the weekly Tuesday ASSU Senate meetings, along with the subcommittee meetings, since October 2009 and actively looking out for the most pressing issues on campus has prepared him to take care of your needs. He knows what needs to be fixed and how to fix it, through the 'SHAWI' plan:   
   


**S**ustainability  

**H**ealth and Wellness  

**A**ppropriations Reform   

**W**elfare of the Arts and Communities   

**I**nternational, Minority, and Faculty Diversity

#SUSTAINABILITY:#
1. Cater to the needs of sustainable groups, including SSS, GLC and ESW.
2. Promote sustainable action plans to protect the environment, such as expanding the Green Events Checklist, more use of energy efficient light bulbs, more carbon emission reduction goals, and continuing to make Stanford Dining sustainable.
3. Ensure effective communication between members of the ASSU, the student body, and the sustainable groups to increase awareness. This requires the continuity of a sustainability subcommittee within the Senate.
4. Minimize the red tape in the bureaucracy at Stanford to resolve issues that are hard to tackle with different channels of command, such as with compost bins that are not accessible everywhere.   

   

#HEALTH AND WELLNESS:#

1. Support the programs that address social and mental issues including the CAPS, MAAN, and the Bridge.
2. Improve the PHE program established in residences by allocating a portion of the dorm’s government funds to the PHE to contribute to healthier residential education.
3. Encourage initiatives that increase awareness about health issues, such as Breast Cancer Awareness Week, Dance Marathon and Relay for Life. 
4. Evaluate effectiveness of health initiatives such as the wellness room and Wellness Week to find ways to improve it.
5. Reestablish the Peer Mentor program for freshmen students to ease the transition to college, and strive to move the add/drop deadline till end of the fourth week of the quarter, instead of third.   
   


#APPROPRIATIONS REFORM:#

1. Create a more transparent system of funding that eliminates inconsistencies by improving communication and defining a standard procedure to procure funds. This will ensure that each group gets ample funding.
2. Advocate more flexible funding. This includes maximizing the utility of our limited funds by allocating them in accordance with each group’s contribution to the student body.
3. Ensure that the appropriations reform will cater to all the other goals I lay out in this platform, which requires increased communication between financial officers and the Senate.
4. Encourage more effective party planning processes, and advocate for longer hours and easier accessibility of places on campus, such as the libraries and Old Union.   

   

#WELFARE OF the ARTS and COMMUNITIES:#

1. Protect the existing arts on campus, such as SICA and the Stanford Concert Network, to allow for more events, concerts, and creativity.
2. Raise awareness of the richness of our campus’s art to increase student involvement with these organizations.
3. Reduce the free speech restrictions on campus, and shorten the current two-week advance notice required for events White Plaza.
4. Meaningfully support the projects and programs of community centers on campus.
5. Build a more effective Acts of Intolerance to tackle hate crimes and abuse on campus at a more profound manner.   
   

#INTERNATIONAL, MINORITY, AND FACULTY DIVERSITY:#

1. Ensure that the admissions considers a 1-2% increase in the international students-which currently comprises around 7.5% of the body-to be on par with our peer schools’ 10%.
2. Increase awareness of the minority and underrepresented ethnicities on campus in attempt to minimize that underrepresentation.
3. Improve faculty diversity through a more diverse graduate body.   

Please join his Facebook group to support this plan and spread the word:
#[Facebook: SHAWI for SENATE] (http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=362844509526&ref=ts “Shawi for Senate”)#
   

Voting takes place online on April 8-9.   
    

Do the SHAWI   

Vote for SHAWI

fields.title: Showly Wang
fields.statement:
I believe that nothing is more important than a vibrant student environment that allows each individual on this campus to live to their fullest and receive the most from their experience on the Farm. I wish to see every individual thriving via strong intellectual engagement, involvement in student groups, and overall happiness and well-being. I believe that serving on the Senate will give me the best avenue to ensure that Stanford is an enriching environment for all, and I hope that you allow me this opportunity by giving me your vote on election day!


**SHOWLY WANG. Small girl, BIG Agenda.**

-----------
The AGENDA:
-----------

1) **CULTIVATE A BETTER RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN STUDENTS & THE SENATE** 
####- To establish a meaningful, long-lasting dialogue that actually incorporates more student voices, the ASSU needs to make itself more open and available to concerned students
>
#####•	ASSU Blog
#####•	Individual Senator Office Hours
#####•	More stringent oversight of discretionary funds
-------------------
2) **IMPROVE THE APPROPRIATIONS PROCESS**
####- For a more "user-friendly" and equitable distribution of funds that has more transparency, accountability, clarity, and accessibility
>
#####•	Published weekly meeting minutes 
#####•	FO surveys to incorporate their input on the process
#####•	Weekly updates to the appropriations website
#####•	Efforts to publicize office hours and various precedents
#####•	Email notifications to the appropriations list of changes in policy
------------------
3) **ENRICH STUDENT LIFE** 
####- To ensure a diverse and thriving student environment which includes:
>
####•	ACADEMICS
#####-Improve advising
#####-Advocate for student groups that foster intellectual engagement 

####•	MENTAL & SEXUAL WELLNESS
#####-Continued support for programs such as SHRPC, The Bridge, CAPS, and others
#####-Expand initiatives surrounding sexual assault

####•	COMMUNITY GROUPS
#####-Implement awareness endeavors for LGBT, cultural, and women’s issues
#####-Integrate Acts of Intolerance protocol into NSO

####•	SUSTAINABILITY
#####-Work to reduce our carbon emissions 
#####-Ensure current sustainability efforts are continued
#####-Encourage the use of the Green checklist for events

####•	SAL REFORM
#####-Eradicate free speech restrictions on campus
#####-Negotiate for less bureaucratic party planning policies
_______________________________________________

Help push the agenda!

Please come out and vote on the elections days April 8 & 9. Thanks for your support!

-Showly Wang

fields.title: Kamil Saeid
fields.statement:
I, Kamil Saeid, pledge to work on the following as an ASSU Senator:

**APPROPRIATIONS**
- Ensuring easy student access to expenditure records and group funding
- Providing students the opportunity to reallocate funds instead of refund them
- Working with financial officers to establish consistent and transparent guidelines for funding requests

**TRANSPARENCY AND ACCOUNTABILITY**
-Establishing and publishing an official senator voting record and meeting attendance log
-Creating a program where student groups can request a senator presence at important meetings

**ACADEMICS**
-Helping to create channels for student entrepreneurship by partnering with venture capitalists
-Bringing attention to loss of grant money and opening discussions for opportunities of fund increase by 5%

**STUDENT EXPERIENCE**
-Expanding 5-SURE Hours as per student request
-Putting on workshops for campus safety, self-defense, and victimization and abuse

**DIVERSITY**
-Partnering with student groups interested in bringing attention to faculty and grad student diversity
-Commissioning a university report (3 students, 1 faculty, 1 administrator) to assess current gender and racial diversity
-Empowering students to take a more active role in finding funding for underrepresented faculty chair endowments

**Endorsed by:** Students of Color Coalition (SOCC) and the Women's Coalition

fields.title: Stewart Macgregor-Dennis
fields.statement:
My name is Stewart Macgregor-Dennis and as you may have heard, I’m running for senate next quarter and I would greatly value your help. As the Frosh Council president for the Class of 2013 (thirteen!), I have made sure to represent the students at every step. If I am lucky enough to be elected as an ASSU senator, I will make sure to continue that trend by raising issues that students care about. I want to fight for:

-	A trustworthy, ethical, and credible ASSU unmarred by scandal.
-	An efficient, cohesive, and collaborative ASSU, without infighting.
-	A senate that proactively interacts with the student body
-	A fair appropriations committee that incorporates financial officers’ input into decisions.
-	
I want to fight for you. I want to be a microphone for the voice of the student body. 

On the Issues:

Transparency and Accountability
-	Make sure each senator visits different dormitories or dining halls on a regular basis.
-	Implement a more transparent and responsive system to check senators’ behavior.
-	Develop an ethical standard for elected officers in the ASSU Constitution
-	Post minutes of ASSU Senate sessions online.

Sustainability:

-	Running a green campaign using only recycled materials
-	Implement and build upon the current version of the Green Events Checklist to encourage environmentally-conscious event planning
-	Advocate for the option of a sustainability GER

Student Life
-	Take additional steps to prevent sexual assault on campus
-	Create more initiatives modeled after the Wellness Week
-	Simplify party planning and permission process through advocacy with the SAL

Appropriations:

-	Establish more consistent guidelines for evaluating funding requests
-	Incorporate financial officers and students into the process of forming and modifying these guidelines
-	Implement guidelines transparently, logically, and consistently
-	Create a feedback system for financial officers to let the ASSU know what works using office hours and questionnaires
-	Expand options for groups to seek and receive outside funding
-	Create a more efficient system for helping groups to work together on events

Diversity
-	Support community centers’ ability to flourish through the allocation of funding 
-	Ensure that all forms of diversity are represented and appreciated
-	Encourage academic diversity
-	Expand awareness of students protections, such as the Act of Intolerance Protocol

Academics 

-	Solicit feedback from the student body on IHUM and work with the administration to implement requested reforms
-	Collaborate with Academic Policies and Regulations committee and the Faculty Senate to ensure that activity classes do not count towards the twenty-unit class limit.

Campus Dialogue
-	Advocate for wider free speech protections and clearer guidelines
-	Make the ASSU an effective mediator between student groups and the administration




Endorsed by the Women’s coalition and GAIA (probably won’t put up yet, then I can send an email out about it later)


http://www.facebook.com/profile.php

fields.title: Nik Milanovic
fields.statement:
**Endorsed By:** The Stanford Democrats, The Stanford Review, The Jewish Student Association, The Green Alliance for Innovative Action, the Stanford InterFraternity Council, [Students United Now](http://studentsunitednow.com), The Stanford Progressive.

[Click here to join the group and help out!](http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=401353644743&ref=mf)

Nik is running for Senate to fix problems he's encountered as an undergraduate.

***

* **Student Group Advocacy**. As the financial officer of a student group, he understands the frustration many students feel with the Senate's handling of Special Fees and other budgetary issues. As a fraternity member, he knows that the administration can be difficult to deal with. His campaign is centered on using the Senate to bridge the communication gap between students and the administration, in order to meet student needs. As a Senator, he will create two public forums to communicate directly with the Senate: one for student groups and one for the entire undergraduate body to express their needs and concerns.

* **Sustainability on Campus**. Nik feels strongly that environmental sustainability is a positive goal for Stanford. As a premier university, Stanford has the power to set an example in the green movement. Nik will work to completely eliminate the use of non-biodegradable cups at campus parties by providing incentives to use eco-friendly cups. He will also push Stanford to pursue initiatives such as green-roofing (growing vegetation on rooftops in order to make them more heat-efficient, trap runoff from rain, and offset carbon dioxide), reducing water consumption from taps and faucets, and tapping renewable energy sources.

* **Expression and Student Voice**. Nik also wants to expand outlets for student voice on campus. Different forums - from political organizations to poetry presentations - are valuable ways to allow students to express themselves to a general audience. Nik will push for more available spaces for groups to make themselves heard on campus by improving students' ability to make their personal and group projects open forum. By protecting student voice, Nik plans to improve free speech and open dialogue policies at Stanford.

* **Protecting Diversity**. Faculty and student diversity are essential to the mission of any premier university, and Stanford is no exception. Among political, ideological, religious, and ethnic groups, student advocacy for diversity is a highly resonant issue. Nik will push for a wide range of backgrounds, perspectives, and group identities. Working for the Undergraduate Senate, Nik will continue Stanford's tradition not only of recognizing all types of diversity but also of maximizing students' exposure to other people of very different backgrounds from their own.

fields.title: Daniel Khalessi
fields.statement:
VIDEO: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vuXhqK0gsXE&feature=player_embedded

ENDORSED BY: Students of Color Coalition (SOCC), Women's Coalition, and Queer Coalition


Below is my platform and why I'm running for ASSU Senate. I hope you will read it, talk to me about it, and join me in my effort to make Stanford the best campus in the world. 


Platform:
I.	Overview: Many students who run for ASSU senate establish similar platforms, using buzzwords like “appropriations reform, fiscal responsibility, transparency, increased communication, mental health, etc. etc. etc.” To them, these words are not grounds for policies or platforms; they are merely strategic tools for winning an election, tools for boosting a resume. As a voter, I view the use of these fictitious buzzwords as deceptive and disingenuous. Thus, as a candidate, I will prioritize these issues and give you specific details about the issues that I advocate. In addition, I won’t simply paint a pretty picture of my platform; I will give you both the benefits and disadvantages of my prospective policies. 

II. Priorities: 

A.	Safeguarding community centers: Like many students on campus, I was initially apathetic to campus politics. I was not particularly interested in running for senate…until I became aware of the disastrous policies that the current senate is making. 

•	Section 1: The Current Senate Appropriations Committee: Spends money on some groups over others without a set standard for how to allocate funds. In the name of “fiscal responsibility,” these senators review clubs on a case-by-case basis and create rules as they go along for determining how funds should be spent. The problem with the current system, however, is that senators who are not affiliated with particular student organizations or who are apathetic to certain organizations for entirely subjective reasons can cut funding from them. For instance, if the a group of senators in the appropriations committee are indifferent toward the American Indian Alliance because they aren’t part of it, they can slash funding from them. This gives the appropriations committee the power to hurt these groups ex post facto from community centers. 

•	Section 2: My plan: I will propose and write legislation that establishes a hierarchy of what types of groups and communities money is spent on with a strong focus on student groups that promote tolerance and diversity. My justification for this is that if the university wants to promote diversity (as it tries to advertise all over the admissions website), it needs to foster a no-less-than-exceptional environment for students of different backgrounds to thrive at Stanford. Student groups that promote tolerance are a way to bring students of these different backgrounds together and thereby foster a more diversity-friendly college environment.

B.	Expanding the pool of money in special fees: The $450,000 in the special fees budget is insufficient for accommodating all of Stanford’s student groups. Idealistically, the ASSU senate would allocate large sums of money to every single student organization and still have enough money left for helping those clubs in an upcoming year. After all, this money belongs to students, not the senate. Realistically, however, the senate will have to hurt some clubs at the expense of others when it comes down to allocating money for special fees; there simply isn’t enough money to go around. Here are two of my proposals for funding clubs in spite of the current monetary restraints:

•	Section 1: Amending the Stanford refund program- 
?	The Status Quo: The ASSU Student Affairs division allows students to request refunds from every single student group on campus during the first two weeks of each quarter. The current program also has privacy restrictions in place that prevents student groups from excluding prospective members based on whether or not they asked for a refund. As a result, students can essentially act as free-riders -- joining various groups, enjoying the benefits of being a part of these groups, and then watching these groups lose money as more and more students demand refunds. An article released by the Editorial Board of the Stanford Daily on February 3rd mentioned that “rates for special fees groups range from 9.6 percent to 18.5 percent, the average being around 16 percent. This amounts to a total of $115,794 for the winter quarter, up from last quarter’s total of $79,604. This quarter’s total of 1,132 refund requests marks the highest number of students asking for refunds in the last three years. The number of students asking for full refunds also hit a three-year high with 379 requests. With over a third of refund-recipients refusing to support any special fees group, it appears that many students simply do not feel the need to contribute to campus organizations, and would rather just keep the money for themselves.” It is no surprise that refunds have taken a major toll on the various clubs and organizations we enjoy on this campus; I thus offer the following change to the current policy:

?	Amendments:
1. Move the deadline for the refund requests to end of the first week of classes every quarter.
2. Give each student organization a database of which students have requested refunds from them immediately after the first week of classes. It will be up to the discretion of these organizations to determine whether or not a student who has requested a refund can join the club. Though this might cause backlash among students who feel that they shouldn't have to pay to join groups, it prevents students from free-riding and better safeguards those groups. 
•	Section 2: Lobbying for more money from the Stanford administration: According to Vice-Provost Boardman, “I think it’s fair to assume that we’re all familiar with the continuing global, national and local economic situation that has produced an unprecedented decline in the University’s endowment, a decline that we estimate is 30 percent. By necessity, offices and departments throughout campus were required to reduce their budgets dramatically and the Student Affairs division had to reduce its general funds operating by $3 million for fiscal year 2010.” Although it is both difficult and ambitious to demand the administration to allocate a larger cut of its endowment to Student Affairs, it is essential. If elected, I will put a senate liaison together to meet with the administration and demand them to take the necessary measures (even if it requires begging alumni for money). 

C. Free Speech- Remove University restrictions on free speech so that students have as much free speech as the First Amendment guarantees them. One concern, however, is about regulating "profanity." For instance, if a fraternity decides to put up offensive ads that objectify women, the University should persuade the frat to take down the posters as opposed to forcefully taking them down.

fields.title: Rahul Sastry
fields.statement:
I hail from Nashville, TN and currently live in Arroyo in the Wilbur complex. In my first two quarters of Stanford, I’ve had the privilege of representing my dorm in Frosh Council, working in the ASSU and a number of student groups on campus. My various experiences have lead me to realize that the ASSU has fallen short on its main responsibility: ensuring that every Stanford student has the college experience that he or she deserves. 

I feel that the ASSU can be much more; I envision a student government that is run by the students for the students. In order to accomplish this overarching goal, I would like to accomplish the following objectives:

* Fair, responsible and sustainable student group funding
* A greater emphasis on sustainability in university policy and campus events
* Programming that encourages dialogue on sexual abuse and diversity
* Guaranteed resources for mental health and wellness resources on campus
* More realistic party-planning regulations that encourage more vibrant student life
* Increased communication with and feedback from the student body
* Less restrictions on campus free speech.

I am proud to be endorsed by the Green Alliance for Innovative Action (GAIA), the Stanford Women’s Coalition and the Stanford Review.

If you would like to be actively involved in my campaign, or simply learn more about my ideals, check out my facebook page at http://snurl.com/sastry4senate, or feel free to email me at rasastry [at] stanford [dot] edu.

fields.title: Noemi Walzebuck
fields.statement:
To begin, here's my favorite YouTube video of all time: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EAcdvmnZ_GM

Sweet. Now it's business time. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WGOohBytKTU

OK, OK. Here we go.

**WHY SHOULD I VOTE FOR NOEMI?**

I may only be a freshman, but I'm already heavily involved with various activities and sectors at Stanford. My experience has given me a good idea of what works and what doesn't. I know what issues affect various interest groups around campus. Additionally, I've made an enormous amount of connections that will be very beneficial. Some of my activities:

- High school Student Body President
- Haas Center Frosh Service Ambassador
- IDEAS Chapter Relations manager
- Students for Engagement and Activism in Microfinance
- Emma Goldman Society for Queer Liberation
- Stanford club tennis
- Stanford Democrats

**WHAT'S YOUR PLAN, NOEMI?**

Issues that I care about and will strive to implement and promote as a Senator:

APPROPRIATIONS COMMITTEE/STUDENT GROUP FUNDING

A few words first: My main goal is expanding student resources to offer more of what's best at Stanford to students. This involves responsibly allocating funds to resources through the Appropriations Committee, which needs a thorough revision of its policies before we begin.

--> Reallocate special fees budget to prioritize the funding of valuable student organizations over buying more flat screens for Old Union. Groups like SSS and the Bridge Peer Counseling Center shouldn't have to worry about financing!
--> Expanded preparatory meetings for groups applying for discretionary and special fees.
--> A full review of specific funding policies to account for tighter budgets.
--> Random audits of student group budgets that receive special fees to ensure fair and responsible spending.
--> Streamlining the refund process to have refund requests take no longer than two weeks.

PROMOTE DIVERSITY

A few words first: I pledge to support community centers and become a voice for minority groups.

--> Introduce the Senate Advisory Board - would allow coalitions and special interest groups to elect a representative to serve as direct advisers to the Senate and advise senators on specific issues. Groups could include GAIA, Women's Coalition, Queer Coalition, SOCC, etc.
--> Lobby for increased faculty and staff diversity.
--> Work on promoting RA training specific to sexuality and gender issues.

HELP SUSTAINABILITY ON CAMPUS

--> Work with Co-Chairs of Sustainability and GAIA to expand "0% Waste" program.
--> Support the Green Events Checklist advocated by SSS.
--> I pledge to run a sustainable campaign! Xerox sustainability paper, woohoo!

RAISE AWARENESS FOR AND IMPROVE ON-CAMPUS MENTAL HEALTH & HEALTH RESOURCES

--> Increase funding for Bridge Peer Counseling Center
--> Improve and expand Wellness Week. Why can't we have something in place every month?
--> Work on improving RA mental health training
--> Increase collaboration with Undergraduate Health & Wellness Chairs
--> Support and work towards a Smoke-Free Stanford.

PROMOTE TRANSPARENCY OF ASSU

--> Collaborate more with other bodies of the ASSU. If elected, I would be a positive force in collaborating with the ASSU Executive, Cabinet, and Frosh Council.
--> Implement "Senate Update", similar to current "ASSU Update", to be emailed to student body and so keeping everyone informed.
--> Integrate the underutilized Frosh Council to work directly with Senate.
--> Common complaint: "No one reads the minutes, why should we post them!" Make it easier to find minutes!

FORMALIZE UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH

--> Create a central database for student research projects, with available faculty supervisors, discussion groups, skills teaching, etc. to streamline undergraduate research at Stanford.

FREE-SPEECH EXPANSION

--> Slow progress better than rapid implementation.
--> Work with Student Activities and Leadership department to ensure that events are within full rights of Partisan Group Policy requirements.
--> Increase hours of free speech and perhaps add an additional location on campus.

**SOUNDS GOOD. IS ANYONE ELSE BACKING YOU?**

Fosho. Endorsements I've received:

- Women's Coalition
- Queer Coalition
- Jewish Student Association
- Colleges Against Cancer

**I WANT TO ASK YOU MORE QUESTIONS!**

Feel free to email me at noewalze@stanford.edu. Or visit me at Arroyo in Wilbur Hall. 

Join the Facebook group at http://www.facebook.com/group.php?v=info&gid=371163409305

fields.title: Michael Cruz
fields.statement:
An Introduction
===================
My name is **Michael Cruz** and I would like to be your Undergraduate Senator. I’ve spent this past year working as a Senator to protect the interests of the Stanford student body. I’ve secured funding for student events and student groups, created a Green Events Checklist and fought for the rights of students. 

Next year, I will continue to be a voice for students who will promote and protect student life in six  specific ways:

1. Ensure funding for student groups and Stanford traditions (such as Full Moon on the Quad and Mausoleum Party)
2. Increase outreach between the ASSU and students with office hours and town halls
3. Ensure ASSU transparency
4. Support the Community Centers
5. Make students events Green with the Green Events Checklist
6. Advocate for more uniform gender-neutral housing


Please contact me at [mecruz@stanford.edu](mecruz@stanford.edu) with any other questions, as I truly want to meet and understand the needs of every undergrad at Stanford.

This April 8 and 9, I ask you to remember to **Keep it in Cruz Control** and vote **Michael Cruz** for ASSU Senator.

To help the Cruz Control Campaign:
==================================
Join the Facebook event at [http://tinyurl.com/cruzcontrol2010](http://tinyurl.com/cruzcontrol2010)

Visit my website at: [http://www.stanford.edu/~mecruz](http://www.stanford.edu/~mecruz)

Contact me at [mecruz@stanford.edu](mecruz@stanford.edu)

fields.title: Stanford Project on Hunger (SPOON)
fields.petition_budget_summary:
Sponsor: Tommy Tobin, ttobin@stanford.edu
Total request: $17,939.88
Requesting from: All undergraduates

You're signing a petition for SPOON's Special Fee request. If approved, all students will pay a portion of this Special Fee on their University bill each quarter. Your signature indicates your support for this fee request and helps it get on the ballot for the ASSU Election on April 8–9. For SPOON's fee request to pass, the group must obtain the signatures of 15% of all undergraduates and must get majority approval on the ballot. If this request does not pass, SPOON is still eligible for $7,000 of ASSU General Fee funding.

The signature form is below the group's budget information.

Statement from SPOON

A large portion of our group's budget will forward our ancillary mission of raising awareness about hunger and poverty issues, supplementing our work reducing food waste & salvaging food.

The events program will be vastly expanded next year. bringing in a bigger-ticket speaker - Dan Glickman, who was Clinton's USDA secretary and current president of the Motion Picture Assoc. of America.

The Conferences are to present our work and move to become the nation's leader in food salvaging efforts.

Appropriations said we are "wasteful" in using one-time-use aluminum containers to salvage the food, spending $3,000-4,000 per year. I attempted to explain that our off-campus partners prefer this system, our on-campus partners use these containers as the industry standard, and there are huge food safety and logistical concerns before we could commit to a reusable system - to no avail. We just can't switch our main operation that quickly - we'd require checking in with the County Supervisor of Health, the Haas Center, Dining, the Opportunity Center, and our other partners to make this a reality.

—

Read the statement from the Undergrad Senate Appropriations Committee

After thoroughly reviewing SPOON's budget and discussing it with Tommy Tobin for over an hour, the Appropriations committee decided to recommend SPOON's budget to a lesser extent for the following reasons:

  1. SPOON's request for funding for disposable tins is not only unsustainable, it is also wasteful. The Appropriations committee recommended that SPOON purchase reusable tins which would be cheaper in the long-run and economical. SPOON flatly rejected that possibility.
  2. A significant part of SPOON's budget goes towards funding trips to multiple conferences around the country. Not only is that against our funding policies, but the Appropriations Committee believes that the student body shouldn't incur the cost of sending [group members] to conferences across the country when they are not necessary to the survival of the group.
  3. SPOON was requesting close to $1000 to replace a fridge that was still completely functional.
  4. The budget recommended by the Appropriations Committee ensures that the groups programming remains intact and that the financial stress on the students is minimized.

    5. — Anton Zietsman, Appropriations Chair, Undergraduate Senate (edit by Elections Commission in square brackets)

SPOON Petition

fields.title: Dan Thompson
fields.statement:
I’m Dan Thompson and I’m running for Senate because I love Stanford and all the incredible student groups, cultural organizations, and other great opportunities available to underclassmen, and I think student government can dramatically improve its understanding and facilitation of these and other student needs.  Specifically **I want to help by making sure resources are appropriated more fairly and to make the whole process of requesting money from the ASSU much easier and more intelligible**.  In addition to handing out money, the Senate should be able to act as a liaison between students and the administration when underclassmen have a problem with how things are run on campus.  That could include issues like social problems on campus (**like faculty diversity, problems with gender neutral housing**), wellness issues (**like high co-pays at Vaden**), free speech issues (**like the two week registration period for White Plaza**) or any other problem that students need the Senate to advocate about.

If elected, I will work with other SUN members and the rest of the Senate to reach out to students so we can better understand how to facilitate YOUR needs.

For a more comprehensive outline of my plan, or to ask me any questions, please visit (and join!) my Facebook group at: http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=372215966139&ref=ts.

fields.title: Senior Package
fields.statement:
As we go into our fourth and final year at Stanford, the Senior Package is excited to continue to bring you all your favorite events from years past along with some exciting new additions. While realizing that our last year may also very well be the most important, our goal is to provide you with the tools you need to survive in life after Stanford while also continuing to make Stanford as fun as it can be. In other words, we’re bringing you the entire **Senior Package**. With over 3 years of class event planning under our belts, we’re using **our** experience to make **your** Senior Year experience the very best. Some of our main plans for next year include:

* Happy Hours: Whether it’s wine tasting in the Skybox or Champagne and Strawberries with President Hennessy, we will work towards making small social events not only more delicious, but also more enriching.
* Workshop Series: We’ll sponsor a variety of workshops tailored to addressing practical skills pertinent to the working world, including etiquette and personal finance.
* Formal: Everyone knows that Senior Formal is always the biggest and the brightest! Keep your calendars open for a great night in the city. 
* Last Lecture Series: We will continue to bring you the Last Lecture series, inviting an esteemed faculty member or alumni each quarter to share advice and experience in what would be their “Last Lecture”. 
* Health & Wellness – We’ll be partnering with the Department of Recreation to bring you events that are not only good fun, they’re good for you! Look out for heart-pumping events like Bagels & OJ at the Dish. 
* Community Service: With an emphasis on service learning, we’ll continue to do the research and compile a list of ongoing campus community service events, making it easier for YOU to get involved. By keeping you informed, we’ll help you get the most out of service learning by allowing you to select the project most tailored to your interests. 
* Alumni Networking events: Don’t know if you should take a few years off or go straight to law school? We’ll help you network with alumni to get some of the best advice and connections Stanford has to offer! 

* And last but not least… Senior Pub Nights: Do they really need an explanation? Whether it’s a hot new club in San Francisco or a traditional local favorite, no senior year is complete without the quintessential pub night experience. 

Making Senior Year the best it can be isn’t possible without you. If you have any suggestions or an event you’d like to see implemented next year, feel free to shoot us an email and we’ll make it happen.

All the best, 
The Senior Package
Dante DiCicco
Pamon Forouhar
Mona Hadidi
Molly Spaeth

fields.title: Pat Bruny
fields.statement:
Hey Stanford, my name is Pat Bruny and I am running to be your ASSU undergraduate senator. Although I am only a freshman, I have gained the necessary experience through my internship with the senate as a senate associate. In this position, I not only learned the inner workings of how the senate works, I also witnessed that Stanford is full of real issues. More importantly, I saw that these issues were headed by real people who were passionate about their cause. This inspired me to run for senate in order to make sure that all voices on campus are heard.

Here is my platform:
1.  Faculty diversity—I will research how other universities are able to keep their faculty and will work with administration in implementing these strategies. 

2.  Acts of Intolerance—I will be working with the diversity advisory board in coding the act of intolerance policy. I will work towards making the policy more transparent and accessible to all students so that justice is never overlooked when an act of discrimination or intolerance occurs. 

3.  Transparency—The Senate is meant to be for the students. I will work to make the senate more transparent by creating a blog on the Stanford homepage so that everyone can easily click the link and get an update on what the senate did for the week. I will also help create a virtual calendar so that students can write down what they would like see to done by the senate.

4.  Funding—Many groups this year have been hurt by budget cuts, increased VSO costs, and lost in special fees. I will work with the appropriations committee to ensure that budget cuts across the boards do not happen, but that careful consideration is given to each group. All people and communities within Stanford deserve to enjoy programs and events. I will ensure that no group is denied funding. 

5.  Sustainability—I will work with all groups in developing events and programs that abide by certain criteria that uphold sustainable practices. I will push for all VSOs to follow the guidelines enacted and practiced by the senate.

6.  Community Centers—Lastly, I will fight for the rights of all community centers. I will attend the different meetings within the major umbrella groups and listen to what they’re concerns are. Stanford is a special place because of its diversity and its many different cultures and personalities. These different groups provide and makeup the home that we all call Stanford.

While this is the platform that I am running on, it by no means expresses all that I want to accomplish. The reason I have not written them down is because I haven’t heard from you yet. The truth is, while these issues are important to me and some people, there are other issues that are just as important. This is why I am running. I want to make Stanford a better place for everyone and in order to do that I need to hear from you. I love Stanford and I would love to have the opportunity to serve you.

You can contact me at my Facebook group at http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=114216418592061&ref=ts or by email at pbruny@stanford.edu.

fields.title: Will Seaton
fields.statement:
My name is Will Seaton and I'm running for ASSU Undergraduate Senate. 

I'm trying to represent you and every member of the student body at Stanford. My policies are focused around making life here on the Farm easier and more pleasant for you. That is why I want to get elected and these are the things I want to do once I get there:



**1.** Increase open communication between the Senate and the student body

**2.** Encourage Senators to facilitate engagement with the student body by going out into the Stanford community

**3.** Make sure Senators are held accountable for their actions.

**4.** Expand sustainability in Old Union and Tressider

**5.** Improve Wellness activity in residences across campus

**6.** Increase dialogue between Financial Officers and the Appropriations Committee so everyone has a say in how they get their funds



For a more detailed plan, please visit and join [my Facebook group](http://www.facebook.com/group.php?v=info&ref=ts&gid=101190706588551)!

I am running to bring the ASSU Senate out of the shadows and back into your life. It has the potential to be so much more than it is right now. As I try to bring life back to the organization, I hope you support my initiatives and **give me your vote on April 8-9**. Lastly, if you believe I would be a good representative, **tell your friends about me!** Spread the word. I can't get elected without you so help my name get out there.

Thank you for reading this and supporting my campaign. **Enjoy springtime on the Farm** and be sure to vote!

-Will Seaton-

Candidate for ASSU Senate

You're signing a petition for The Stanford Daily's Special Fee request. If approved, all students will pay a portion of this Special Fee on their University bill each quarter. Your signature indicates your support for this fee request and helps it get on the ballot for the ASSU Election on April 8–9. For The Stanford Daily's fee request to pass, the group must obtain the signatures of 15% of all undergraduates and must get majority approval on the ballot. If this request does not pass, The Stanford Daily will still be eligible to receive $53,700 in ASSU Special Fee funding that was recommended by the Senate for next year (if approved by voters), instead of the $89,500 they are requesting.

The signature form is below the group's budget information.

Statement from The Stanford Daily

Stanford Daily writers and editors (over 200) work tremendously hard every day to break news and cover key issues relevant to your lives. We publish 145 times a year, deliver to over 200 locations on campus and host our content for free on our website.

The past 18 months have been brutal for newspapers everywhere—we’ve slashed our budget by over $100,000 and as we battle a 35% drop in advertising revenue, we’re asking for a modest Special Fees increase.

20 years ago, our alumni created a separate foundation to ensure the long-term survival of The Daily (as have alumni at Yale Daily News and the Harvard Crimson). Two of our staff sit on the board of the foundation, but they don’t directly control the funds—the Chairman of the board does.

We believe there are few organizations on campus that provide such a direct, measurable and useful service to the student body than The Daily. With your support, we can continue to serve as the campus paper of record for many years to come.

The Stanford Daily Petition

Have you applied for Special Fees in the past 3 years? If so, please detail the outcome of each attempt.

Yes - we have received our requested funding in 2007-08, 2008-09 and 2009-10.

If you applied for Special Fees last year, is there an increase in the amount you're seeking this year? If so, why?

Yes. Ad sales have been hit hard at The Daily, and we are down around 40% from 2007-08. The entire industry has seen 9 consecutive quarters of double digit declines in revenue. Newspapers across the country are raising their subscription fees and we are raising our special fees funding in a similar fashion.

Please define the services provided by your group with the Special Fee, as per the ASSU Constitution:

The Stanford Daily has been a fixture on the Stanford campus since the University was founded in 1891. The paper began as a small publication called The Daily Palo Alto and has grown to its current status as one of the finest college newspapers in the country. The Daily is published Monday through Friday during the academic year and is delivered to over 200 locations on campus and over 700 locations around the surrounding mid-Peninsula communities. It has a staff of over 200 editors, writers and business people. We are the campus paper of record.

What are the three largest line item requests in your budget and why?

Printing: We have reduced our spend on printing by nearly 20% from 2008-09 while trying to still get all the major stories into the paper. Overhead: Our overhead costs have been the most difficult to lower and this is the challenge of an established organization. Still, we have reduced our overhead from previous years despite large increases in insurance, phone and utility bills as mandated by the University. Staff Salaries: Our editors put 20-30 hours a week into the paper and we pay the minimum wage for their efforts - far less than they deserve. We also employ several professional staff; some are recent grads, others who have been working for us for many years. We cut editorial pay by nearly 30% from last year, reduced professional staff wages by 5% and let go of a long time ad designer.

What is the average attendance at your events?

Our surveys indicate that 89% of Stanford students pick up the paper once a week or more. Overall, 65% of Stanford students, faculty and staff read The Daily once a week or more, and many members of the local community read it off campus. This works out to 17,000+ people per week reading The Daily.

Please list all:1) assets, 2) reserves, 3) authorized and unauthorized non-ASSU bank accounts, 4) sources of funding other than Special

1) As of Jan 31, 2010, our total assets stood at $525,613.61 with $158,114.24 in cash. (For comparison, Jan 31, 2009, assets - $643,366.04, cash -$450,846.00. Jan 31, 2008, assets $781,639.00, cash - $561,025.) The Daily has received an exemption from the ASSU banking system, so we have bank accounts with Wells Fargo, Stanford Federal Credit Union, and Fidelity. In addition to Special Fees, we receive donations from alumni, sell subscriptions and ads in our paper and on our website to support our operations.

What events/programs does your group hold throughout the year for the Stanford Community?

We don't typically host events - our main role is covering the news and delivering it to the student body and the community at large.

Why are you requesting Special Fees?

The Stanford Daily is the oldest and one of the most visible student groups on campus. We provide a major service to the student body and incur major costs to provide this service. Special Fees is the way for Stanford students to fund a fraction of our operating expenses.



Miscellaneous information

Sources of Funding Other Than General and Special Fees

Print Advertising, Print Subscribers, Online Advertising, Alumni donations

Reason for Seeking Undergraduate-Only Special Fee

We are seeking undergraduate funding because 95+% of our staff are undergraduates. A recent survey indicated that 89% of undergraduates pick up the Daily once a week or more. We do not have any recent data on graduate readership.

List of current assets as of Jan 31, 2010

Cash: Wells Fargo: $42,411.82; Stanford Fed. Credit Union: $115,125.25; Other Cash: $577.17
Accounts Receivable: $206,464.20
Prepaid Insurance: $5,677.84
Prepaid Expenditures: $36,545.73
Other Current Assets: $6,218
Total Assets: $414,200.14

fields.title: Carolyn Simmons
fields.statement:
As Program Manager for The Riordan Foundation, founded by former Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles, **Carolyn Simmons provided educational resources to under-performing schools, especially those in low-income communities**, for a year before coming to Stanford. Collaboration with public officials, school faculty members, concerned parents, and students inspired Carolyn’s dedication to addressing the diverse interests and needs of all students.

At Stanford, **Carolyn is an active member of the ASSU**, serving as an Executive Fellow for the Public Service Committee. She considers the opportunity to address needs of undergraduate student body the ultimate form of service. 

**An experienced decision-maker in the ASSU and among Los Angeles County public officials**, Carolyn [cares](http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=269040919989&ref=ts) about:

1. **CREATING OPPORTUNITIES**
       * Simplify SAL event and party planning
       * Advocate for free speech on campus by reducing administrative red-tape
2. **CREDIBILITY**
       * Implement open, transparent and consistent funding processes by regularly posting meeting minutes and by providing preparatory guidance for financial officers
      * Establish office hours to enhance communication between senators and students
      * Designate a formal liaison to appropriately answer student questions and collect feedback
3. **CAUSES**
      * Ensure the University commits to Service Summit 2009 ten-year objectives
      * Explore adding a sustainability subject area to Education for Citizenship GER requirement

Carolyn has been endorsed by:
1. **Green Alliance for Innovative Action**
2. **Women’s Coalition**
3. **Colleges Against Cancer**
4. **The Stanford Review**
5. **Jewish Student Association**

Show that you care too!
1. Contact Carolyn via [facebook](http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=269040919989&ref=ts) and join others who support her
2. [Email](mailto:csimmons@stanford.edu) Carolyn about issues that you care about and see them addressed this upcoming year.

fields.title: Sophs 4 More
fields.statement:
Hey **THIRTEEN!**, we're Sophs4More.

Our college experience has been off to a great start with an excellent freshman year, but we from **Sophs4More** believe that So Much More can and should be done to make our sophomore year even better. 

As members of the Frosh Council, **Shane Hegde** and **Steven Greitzer** have had the opportunity to plan and implement events for the entire class. With the addition of the fresh and visionary perspectives of **Misha Nasro** and **Maxine Litre**, we have come up with some glorious and epic ideas for next year! The four of us would feel so honored to have the opportunity to work together to give you the most exciting and eventful sophomore year you can imagine. 

Class of ’13, you deserve **So Much More** from your student government, and we from Sophs4More are ready to give you just that!

With Love,
Misha, Steven, Maxine, and Shane

____________________________________________________________________________________________________


**Our Plan:**


**1. Full Moon on the Quad… feat. Super Mash Bros!**

*   Goodbye swine flu, hello mash-up music, make-outs, and Stanford traditions galore. Maybe FMOTQ is meant for freshmen… but we need our chance to kiss the tree too! We are already discussing this with the SMB themselves!

**2. SOPHisticated Sophomore Formal**

*   Think dazzle, class, and magnificence. Pair that with bowties, high heels, and a San Francisco venue, and you get pure SOPHistication. 

**3. Sophomore-Senior Mentorship**

*   Sophomores talk to seniors about majors, classes, and professors… helping each other get real information before declaring.

**4. Lock-In in Green Library**

*   Laser tag in the stacks anyone? We’ve contacted Green Library and they’re excited to make a bash out of books!

**5. San Francisco Events**

*   Sophomore Scavenger Hunt – like Freshmen Scavenger Hunt… but better!

*   Giants Game – Taaake me out to a baaall game with 2013.

*   Trolley Tour – A classic way to see this beautiful city.

**6. Epic Sophomore Tailgate for the USC Football Game**

*   55-21. That’s all that needs to be said. Go Cardinal!

**7. “Off-the-Row” Fridays**

*   Group Dinners at Palo Alto Restaurants – Food, fun, and friends in a whole new atmosphere and an affordable price!

*   Comedy and Jazz Clubs – Whether it’s for a good laugh or a soothing sound, these trips are a great getaway.

*   Café Nights – Watch other sophomores show off their talents.

**8. Faculty "Last Lecture" Series**

*   Inspired by Carnegie Mellon professor Randy Pausch, Sophs4More would like to invite faculty members to give their "Last Lecture" in hopes to reveal the more personal side of our renowned lecturers.   

**9. Watch Me Grow!**

*   As Earth Day approaches, we want to inspire Palo Alto youth to conserve our environment through planting, gardening, and practicing eco-friendly activities.

fields.title: Leland Stanford Junior University Marching Band
fields.petition_budget_summary:
Sponsor: Georgia Andrews, money@lsjumb.com
Total request: $77,200.00
Requesting from: All undergraduates

You're signing a petition for the Leland Stanford Junior University Marching Band's Special Fee request. If approved, all students will pay a portion of this Special Fee on their University bill each quarter. Your signature indicates your support for this fee request and helps it get on the ballot for the ASSU Election on April 8–9. For the Band's fee request to pass, it must obtain the signatures of 15% of all undergraduates and must get majority approval on the ballot. If this fee request fails to pass, the Band can still receive up to $6,000 in ASSU General Fee funding.

The signature form is below the group's budget information.

Proposed budget for 2010-2011 (total request $77,200)

Event: General Operating Expenses










Line Item


Amount Requested


Description






6110 – Officer Salary


$8,400.00


This line item compensates the Manager and Assistant Manager for their service to the Band throughout the year. We pay these individuals on a quarterly basis. The Manager salary is $1500 for fall quarter and $1400 for winter and spring, and the Assistant Manager salary is $1400 for fall quarter and $1300 for winter and spring. This small stipend helps to honor the service of two students who often give more time to the Band than a full-time job would require. We also request $100 to cover processing fees.

6340 – Security Services


$10,000.00


This line item mainly covers security expenses for the fall and spring band runs. These rallies are very important events for the student body. We are required to pay for police at these events in order to keep the participants and property safe. The fall rally generally costs about $7000. We budget an additional $3000 for the spring rally.

6560 – Event Food


$3,500.00


The Band has significant food and drink expenses in order to provide for its large membership, especially during football season. We provide a small breakfast to the full football band prior to every Saturday field rehearsal, since these rehearsals must be scheduled before the dining halls open. This costs about $1000 for the season. Occasionally football schedules also prohibit band members from eating lunch and/or dinner at dining halls; we provide a meal in those situations, this is about $500. We also provide drinks and water during sporting events to stay hydrated, which costs about $500. We also require $500 for miscellaneous food for large recruiting and social events. Lastly, the Band plays for a variety of off-campus community service events throughout the year that often overlap with dining hall hours; we budget $1000 to provide a small meal for members on those occasions.

7120 – Phone


$1,600.00


Our landline phone in the Band Shak costs about $130 per month, billed all twelve months of the year. Additional other expenses are required on occasion. It is essential that we have a phone in the Shak so we can be reached about performance opportunities, and Band management needs to be able to make calls frequently. We therefore request $1600 to maintain our phone service.

7130 – Postage/Courier


$350.00


We require some money for postage in order to maintain our Post Office box, which receives bills from companies we work with, as well as correspondence from alumni and people interested in the Band program. Additionally, we need to mail out materials throughout the year to maintain contacts with our community.

7140 – Copies (not marketing)


$5,100.00


Photocopying expenses are essential to the Band. We require large expenses every quarter in order to make enough copies of our music for the entire Band. For fall quarter, these costs are estimated at $700, and $300 for winter and spring quarters. Additionally, we require $150 to maintain our archives in the Shak Library. We also need about $450 to produce our handbook, which serves as our primary recruiting material. The lease on our in-house Xerox machine is about $170/month, plus $290 a quarter for usage. We need a machine in the Shak because it is more convenient (as well as cheaper) for copying small batches of music in the middle of the quarter. The Shak copier is also used for administrative copies and field charts during football season.

7150 – Office Supplies


$600.00


 We require miscellaneous expenses throughout the year for staples, pens, paper, letterhead, mailing envelopes, and videotape.

7220 – Marketing Copies/Print Expenses


$150.00


 This line item covers recruiting and advertising for Dollies, Tree, Writers, Announcers, Fall and Spring recruiting efforts. We require paper fliers and other marketing materials throughout the year.

7410 – Equipment Purchase (Non-Cap)


$23,800.00


This is our largest line item. We require money to purchase instruments, uniforms, and materials for our field shows, as well as other expenses throughout the year. I will enumerate this line item based on how we categorize our expenses. Acquisitions. The Band provides an instrument to every member of the band. These instruments require consumable maintenance supplies on an ongoing basis. The woodwind sections require reeds, neck straps, mouthpieces, and cleaners ($4500 per year), the brass sections require lubricants and mouthpieces ($2000 per year), and the drums require sticks and replacement heads ($2000 per year). In addition, we request $1000 for the purchase of new hardware and cymbals for the drum set. Total: $9,500. Computers and technology hardware. We require consumable computer supplies such as disks throughout the year, for an estimated cost of $300. Total: $300. Props. The Band's field shows are an integral part of each Stanford football game. We write two new shows for every home game and at least one road game (not including Big Game), and we require building materials and paint to make props for each show at an estimated $250 for each show. Total: $1750. Other hardware. Additionally, we require building materials and hardware to keep up our Shak throughout the year, unrelated to the field shows. Total: $3500. Cases. We require new cases as they become worn out. We need cases to safely transport our instruments to away games for football, basketball and women’s volleyball. Total: $500. Uniforms. We require a significant amount of money to provide costumes and uniforms for the Band. The Drum Major requires $4000 for costumes throughout the year. The majority of this money ($2800) is spent during football season, at about $350 for each home game, as well as Big Game, one road game, and a possible Bowl Game, and the rest ($1200) is spent during winter and spring quarter. The expenses of the Drum Major are necessary to maintain the spirit and appearance of the Band at all of its performances. The Tree serves to provide spirit and visibility for the Band and for Stanford, and we request $2500 for the Tree costume. Lastly, the Band purchases uniform hats for all its members once a year, for $1750. Total: $8250.

7430 – Equipment Maintenance


$10,700.00


Due to the large amount of property the Band maintains, we have significant maintenance expenses. Dry-cleaning our uniforms annually costs about $1100. We request $3000 for repairs to the valves and tubing of our trumpets, mellophones, and trombones, as well as $500 for drum repairs. Repairs to bits, necks, and tubing for our sousaphones cost about $2600, and repadding our woodwinds, fixing dents, and adjusting metal carriages will cost an estimated $3000. We also request $500 for miscellaneous repairs to other items such as the tree costume and graphics tower.

7460 – Costumes/Uniforms


$7,000.00


This line item covers uniforms for the Dollies. They require $1400 per quarter for their dresses, as well as $600 per quarter for shoes, make-up, hair ribbons, pom poms, dance spankies, and other accessories. The Dollies also require once-a-year expenses of $1000 for luggage and tracksuits.

7730 – Car/Van Rental


$6,000.00


This line item covers transportation to Band events when private cars are not a viable option. We estimate a $4000 expense for the annual UC Davis band competition in spring quarter, and an additional $2000 for buses to various other performances throughout the year, such as Big Game rallies in San Francisco.

Total:

Repairs to bits, necks, and tubing for our sousaphones cost about $2600, and repadding our woodwinds, fixing dents, and adjusting metal carriages will cost an estimated $3000.

7460 – Costumes/Uniforms


$7,000.00


This line item covers uniforms for the Dollies. They require $1400 per quarter for their dresses, as well as $600 per quarter for shoes, make-up, hair ribbons, pom poms, dance spankies, and other accessories. The Dollies also require once-a-year expenses of $1000 for luggage and tracksuits.

7730 – Car/Van Rental


$6,000.00


This line item covers transportation to Band events when private cars are not a viable option. We estimate a $4000 expense for the annual UC Davis band competition in spring quarter, and an additional $2000 for buses to various other performances throughout the year, such as Big Game rallies in San Francisco.

Total:


$76,642.00





Current account statements







Miscellaneous information

Estimates and descriptions of planned expenses for the remainder of the current year

  • Officer Salary - $2,400.00: Salary for the manager and assistant manager for spring quarter, plus $100 for processing fees.
  • Security Services - $3,000.00: Spring band run security.
  • Event Food - $2,150.00: We have multiple early morning rallies in the spring where we provide a small breakfast, as well as food for recruiting efforts, meals for Battle of the Bands in Davis, and water for spring band run.
  • Phone - $1,050.00: It costs $131/month, and we need to pay for November through June.
  • Postage/Courier - $100.00: Estimated expenses for mailing reunion-related materials.
  • Copies (not marketing) - $1,300.00: Our estimated copier lease expenses for the rest of the year are $850, $300 to print music for the spring, and $150 for printing other materials.
  • Office Supplies - $180.00: For copier paper, rings for folders, pens, etc.
  • Marketing Copies/Print Expenses - $100.00: For spring recruiting fliers and and Facebook ads.
  • Equipment Purchase (non-cap) - $8,800.00: $2000 for instrument supplies such as drumsticks, reeds, and mouthpieces. $1500 for costumes for the manager and drum major. $1000 for the new tree costume. $2000 for shak upkeep and equipment. $300 for computer hardware. $2000 for instrument and rally storage.
  • Equipment Maintenance - $5,000.00: We are planning on repairing a large percentage of our instruments in the next few months. We expect these repairs to cost about $5000.
  • Costumes/Uniforms - $2,400.00: The Dollie dresses for spring will cost about $1600, and other uniform costs for the new Dollies will use the remaining $800.
  • Car/Van Rental - $5,300.00: Buses to the Davis Day Battle of the Bands is estimated at $3300, and travel to Cal for sporting events is estimated at $2000.

Note about account statement

There are 5 or 6 pending transactions at the time of this email that are NOT reflected in the attached account statement, but ARE reflected in the budget table.

Reason for seeking undergrad-only Special Fees

We are seeking undergraduate special fees, as 90%-95% of our regular membership is made of of undergraduates.

List of current assets (capital equipment, etc.)

We have a checking and savings account with the ASSU, with a total of about $9,100. We also own a large collection of instruments in varying states of repair, an old Mac desktop, and some speakers, along with miscellaneous tools and equipment.

Sources of funding other than Special and General Fees, including but not limited to, alumni donations, corporate donations, grants, funding from other University units, endowment payouts

Some of our travel and food expenses are covered by the athletic department.
fields.statement:
Our mission is to bring mirth and merriment to the world and happiness to all those within earshot. We put the bounce in your step, the twinkle in your eye, and maybe the quiver in your loins. We support Stanford Athletics and provide Stanford spirit to the community, and give people everywhere a sonic reminder that Stanford University is an awesome place. Basically, we’re all about fun—having it, making it, and bringing it to the rest of the Stanford community.

The Stanford Band requests Special Fees because we serve the Stanford community in its entirety, which causes our daily operating expenses to be quite large. Unlike other college marching bands, the Stanford Band does not receive complete funding from its Athletic Department. Also unlike other bands, we serve the student population in a unique way, and we feel it is appropriate to ask the student body to help us continue to provide school spirit for all.

fields.title: Green Living Council
fields.petition_budget_summary:
Sponsor: Kevan Christensen kevanc@stanford.edu
Total request: $9,823.90
Requesting from: All undergraduates

You're signing a petition for Green Living Council's Special Fee request. If approved, all students will pay a portion of this Special Fee on their University bill each quarter. Your signature indicates your support for this fee request and helps it get on the ballot for the ASSU Election on April 8–9. For GLC's fee request to pass, it must obtain the signatures of 15% of all undergraduates and must get majority approval on the ballot. If this fee request fails to pass, GLC can still receive up to $6,000 in ASSU General Fee funding.

The signature form is below the group's budget information.

Statement from Green Living Council

The Green Living Council is a group dedicated to raising awareness about sustainability and environmental issues on campus. We recruit, train, and support a network of volunteer Green Living Coordinators in dorms and houses across campus. These coordinators work to promote a culture of sustainability through residential programming and projects. Our many projects include the Conservation Cup, a fall-quarter course, a Green Screens Environmental Series each quarter, the Green Living Pledge, providing shower timers and laundry racks for students in residences, and more.

Our organization continues to grow, and we believe we can have an even greater impact in promoting sustainability on campus with a larger and more institutionalized budget. Thus far, we have relied on smaller project-based grants and have been unable to undertake our ideal projects due to budget constraints. As a large group that has the potential to reach students all across campus with a positive message of sustainability, we believe that a Special Fees budget will allow us to greatly increase our impact and the benefits we provide to the campus.

—

Read explanation from the Senate Appropriations Committee about why they didn't recommend this request

The Appropriations Committee chose not to recommend the following budget for Special Fees. The GLC budget far exceeds the Committee's policies for multiple line items. They have requested $3,000 for banners, which the Committee decided was excessive. Furthermore, the relatively small size of the GLC's Special Fees request suggests that it is best suited for the General Fee, where it can access a reliable and sizeable amount of money which should be more than sufficient to fund the operation of this young group. We have encouraged the GLC to seek General Fee funding as it continues to expand its operations and pursue Special Fees funding in the future.

— Undergraduate Senate Appropriations Committee
