Application questions

Have you applied for Special Fees in the past 3 years? If so, please detail the outcome of each attempt.

No

If you applied for Special Fees last year, is there an increase in the amount you're seeking this year? If so, why?

N/A

Please define the services provided by your group with the Special Fee, as per the ASSU Constitution:

The Green Living Council provides the entire Stanford campus with greater awareness about the existing environmental situation and encourages behavioral change through a grassroots level that gets everyone involved and aware of the issues, the possibilities, and the alternatives made ready for every individual out there. The GLC does more than just impact its members to make change, but they in turn spread their own passions and enthusiasms to the rest of the dorms and the rest of the Stanford campus through different projects and events. For a VSO that makes such a large impact, we are asking for a little more than our normal expenditure budget and hope to make an even bigger impact on a more deeper and sustainable level than the existing changes that have been implemented.

What are the three largest line item requests in your budget and why?

Event Supplies- These are all necessary items for our interventions and projects as well as for our annual Conservation Cup and Fall Quarter class. These are the foundations of the GLC and what we dedicate ourselves to, our approach to the environmental sustainability issue at hand. Marketing Supplies- This is to better promote our group and what we do, especially making our work known to others for greater cooperation and attracting a larger student base. Printing Supplies- This is for greater visibility throughout campus of our events and just a way for dorms to show support and generate greater awareness to the entire student body.

What is the average attendance at your events?

Attendance varies for each event. For our Residence Interventions, Green Screens may result in 15-20 residents and a solid 80% of residents for shorter showers. For our Symposium, roughly 30 attendees show up and for our Conservation Cup, roughly 15 dorms participate with varying numbers per dorm.

How do you plan to publicize your events/programs to the greater Stanford community? Have you registered with Events at Stanford?

Yes. We hope to utilize our website, e-flyers, chalking and getting the word out through our GLC members. In addition, publicity materials will further enhance our visibility and our events.

Please list all:1) assets, 2) reserves, 3) authorized and unauthorized non-ASSU bank accounts, 4) sources of funding other than Special Green Fund,

Student Housing & Mel Lane Student Program Grants. [See below for more information.]

What events/programs does your group hold throughout the year for the Stanford Community?

Conservation Cup, a diverse range of dorm events ranging from panels to discussions to movie showings, a class, a dorm leader who keeps the dorm updated and actively focused on sustainability efforts, residential interventions, and a GLC Symposium for the entire Stanford population to benefit from.

Why are you requesting Special Fees?

This year, we are hoping to expand even more than before. We realized the limitations we faced due to monetary confinements and how that hindered many of us from doing a lot more and making a much greater impact than we already have. As we become more and more of an established student group with greater prominence within residences (we worked with the RA's this year which was a drastic improvement from last year and now we are hoping to gain the support of RF's as well), we hope to further develop that impact without financial resources as a constraint. We all have great ideas and plans to implement, and we do have the administrative support as well as a large student body support, but we don't have the financial support to do so. Special Fees will help us overcome that.

Miscellaneous information

Estimates and descriptions of planned expenses for the remainder of the current year

  • $1000 – Earth Day campus-wide banner event
  • $520 – Green Living Council Symposium
  • $50 – Printing and publicity costs
  • $30 – Social event costs (ice cream social, cookie-baking film screening, etc.

Reason for seeking undergrad-only Special Fees

We are seeking undergrad fees because we mostly serve the undergrad student body and we are entirely made up of undergraduate Stanford students.

List of current assets (capital equipment, etc.)

  • 14 large and 26 small laundry racks
  • Approximately 80 shower timers
  • 8 Kill-A-Watt electricity meters
  • Art and office supplies
  • Button-making materials
  • Publicity materials

Sources of funding other than Special and General Fees, including but not limited to, alumni donations, corporate donations, grants, funding from other University units, endowment payouts

Student Housing & Mel Lane Student Program Grants
fields.statement:
The Green Living Council is dedicated to recruiting, training, and supporting the network of volunteer Green Living Coordinators working in dorms and houses across campus to promote sustainable behaviors. We sponsor sustainability programming including the Conservation Cup, Green Screens Environmental Documentary Series, Green Living Pledge, GLC Symposium, and Stand Together for a Greener Future campaign.  In addition, we offer a training course for our members and also provide support for residence projects such as shower timers and laundry drying racks.  We are seeking Special Fees in order to strengthen and expand all of our programming next year and better serve the campus community.


Please note: Although we do have a great and dedicated team of Green Living Coordinators, we do not currently have over 100 active members as stated in some materials below and elsewhere.  This was a figure based on initial recruitment at the start of the academic year.

fields.title: Rebecca Sachs
fields.statement:
Rebecca Sachs, a financial officer, journalist, and campus activist, wants to promote pragmatic and transparent policies that enhance the quality of the Stanford experience.

Rebecca is endorsed by ** The Jewish Student Association, Queer Straight Alliance, Women’s Coalition, Green Alliance for Innovative Action, Colleges Against Cancer, and The Stanford Review.**

Rebecca’s ideas include:

**Strengthening student input on University policies**

* Simplify SAL’s **party and event planning process** in order to decrease stringent regulations and create a more vibrant campus social scene.
* Increase student input on decisions surrounding student life, housing, and academics by **lobbying for student-backed reforms** and pressuring the administration to run decisions by student representatives.
* Reduce administrative barriers that hinder students’ rights to **free speech**.

**Fostering accountability within the ASSU**

* Improve the **student group funding process** by creating clearer, more mutual guidelines and instituting a review process for groups whose budgets deserve re-evaluations.
* Increase **communication with the student body** through monthly Senate updates and collaboration with dorms and student groups.
* Reinforce **ethical behavior** in the ASSU by increasing oversight of discretionary funds and better publicizing agendas and bills.

**Improving student resources**

* Promote **sexual health and tolerance** by ensuring that proven programs like SHPRC receive funds and increasing resources for the Queer community on campus.
* Enhance the **academic advising program** and **Judicial Affairs** process so they can **better serve students**.
* Further students’ ability to live **sustainable lifestyles** by promoting the Green Events Checklist and supporting GLC initiatives.

Feel free to [contact Rebecca Sachs](malito: rmsachs@stanford.edu) and visit her [Facebook page](http://www.facebook.com/group.php?v=wall&ref=ts&gid=106192936082127).

fields.title: Two Dope Boys in a Caddylack
Deepa Kannappan
fields.statement:
Hey Stanford Undergrads! 
I'm running for ASSU Senate to ensure the quality and pure amazingness of the Stanford community, academic and extracurricular. These are my three main goals:

1. Institute an "Acts of Intolerance Checklist" for ASSU funded events.

2. Increase funding for groups that support the diverse Stanford community.

3. Create peer advising programs for undergraduates.


A more detailed PLATFORM:

*Diversity and Tolerance*

1. An Act of Intolerance is conduct that adversely and unfairly targets an individual or group on the basis of race, gender, sexual orientation, age, disability, religion, or nationality. Acts of Intolerance go largely unaddressed by the ASSU. I propose an **“ASSU against Acts of Intolerance” Checklist** for all ASSU funded events. This checklist would list requirements such as “this event flyer will not include lewd images” or “this event will not insult or take actions against campus ethnic, religious, and LGBT communities.”

2. I will advocate for **RA training on ethic and LGBT issues** so that they are more capable of supporting their residents if they are racially conflicted or decide to come out. I will also fund expansion of the SOSAS program and Ally program. Both of these policies will promote open discussion and tolerance in the residences.

*Peer Advising*

1. A few years ago, dorm staff included academic versions of RAs. These students acted as **academic peer advisors** that helped freshmen and sophomores with class selections and recommendations. These staff positions were eliminated as a result of funding cuts.

2. I propose using the funds of the Student Life, Housing, and Education Committee to build up a program in Sweet Hall, similar to the Peer Tutoring program, which will bring back academic peer advising to undeclared undergraduates.

*Increased Funding for Student Groups*

1. Groups are already facing funding cuts from the faculty and administration; it is the Senate’s 
job to act as a **support system, not a vetting system** for these groups.

2. While it is true that the ASSU cannot keep spending at the rate it was two years ago (which was close to 90cents for every dollar asked), this past Senate’s policies far more restricting than necessary.

3. I propose maintaining the current guidelines for fund requests, but increasing FO training and being more lenient to groups that put in the time to follow procedure.

*Sustainability*

1. **Fund GAIA and GLC** so that they can do what they do best.*

2. Follow the Green checklist for all ASSU funded events.

3. Promote a green implementation of all policies (i.e. advertise online or through videos rather than by flyers)

*Transparency*

1. *It’s not just about telling the student body what the Senate is doing, but why we do it. We must explain ourselves every step of the way so that there is **no room for distrust**.

2. Increase opportunities for student feedback through town halls and voter approval surveys.

Special Fees application PDF

http://elections.stanford.edu/special-fees/petitions/vila/vila-app.pdf



Application questions

Have you applied for Special Fees in the past 3 years? If so, please detail the outcome of each attempt.

Yes. We have applied for special fees the last three years and each time we had the budget voted on and passed by the student body.

If you applied for Special Fees last year, is there an increase in the amount you're seeking this year? If so, why?

Yes. Due to the increase in the ticket prices in the last year, the inflationary increase of 2.7% of the budget was added for plane tickets in order to offset the increase in costs.

Please define the services provided by your group with the Special Fee, as per the ASSU Constitution:

Volunteers in Latin America is a grassroots organization committed to sustainable development and social improvement community initiatives. The purpose is to provide students with a hands-on learning experience while contributing to community work projects.

What are the three largest line item requests in your budget and why?

The three largest line items are officer salaries, travel to Ecuador, and accomodations for stays there. Officer salaries are help the officers to offset the cost of living in Ecuador and are payment for all the work needed to organize an international trip. Travel to Ecuador covers a small part of the plane tickets for the volunteers in order to make the trip more affordable and accomodations cover the living arrangments for the volunteers during the two months.

What is the average attendance at your events?

Volunteers in Latin America takes around 11 people to Ecuador for 2 months during the summer. In each of past couple of years we have ranged from 40 to 60 applications for the program.

How do you plan to publicize your events/programs to the greater Stanford community? Have you registered with Events at Stanford?

We flyer campus and send emails out to all the lists drawing a variety of different applicants for the program.

Please list all:1) assets, 2) reserves, 3) authorized and unauthorized non-ASSU bank accounts, 4) sources of funding other than Special

Our current assets are $22,434.17. Our reserves are $782.99 and our funding primarily comes from special fees however we have had donations from various departments. We also charge a program fee however, we help pay for whatever the volunteers cannot cover.

What events/programs does your group hold throughout the year for the Stanford Community?

Volunteers in Latin America organizes a summer trip to Quito, Ecuador where students get a hands on experience at grassroots community service, working in some of the poorest areas of Quito. Once back at Stanford, VILA encourages its members to take part in community events and organizes various different presentations drawing attention to the problems associatied with street and working children.

Why are you requesting Special Fees?

We are requesting special fees because due to the high costs of the trip, travel and accomodations, we would be unable to afford all the expenditures.

Miscellaneous information

Reason for seeking undergrad-only Special Fees

We are seeking undergrad special fees. We are petitioning because the recommendations suggested by the appropriations committee greatly endanger the sustainability of our group in the near future. If these modifications were enacted, the fees charged to the participants of the group would have to be increased substantially. It would also become much harder to recruit qualified leaders responsible for the safety and well being of VILA volunteers throughout their two month stay in Ecuador.

List of current assets (capital equipment, etc.)

Our current assets are $22434.17. Only $10,911.18 is money that can be spent without restrictions and this sum is non renewable for the most part.

Sources of funding other than Special and General Fees, including but not limited to, alumni donations, corporate donations, grants, funding from other University units, endowment payouts

We charge 900 to all members however this goes to cover airfare and we do not receive revenue from this. We have received donations from various departments however in the last couple years this usually added up to onlya couple hundred dollars. Our main source of funds is special fees.

fields.title: Basmati Raas
fields.petition_budget_summary:
Sponsor: Ali Habib, ali.habib@stanford.edu
Total request: $16,000
Requesting from: All undergraduates

You're signing a petition for Basmati Raas's Special Fee request. If approved, all students will pay a portion of this Special Fee on their University bill each quarter. Your signature indicates your support for this fee request and helps it get on the ballot for the ASSU Election on April 8–9. For Basmati Raas's fee request to pass, it must obtain the signatures of 15% of all undergraduates and must get majority approval on the ballot. If this fee request fails to pass, Basmati Raas will still be eligible for $10,380 in Special Fees funding recommended for it by the Senate (if approved by voters).

The signature form is below the group's budget information.

Statement from Basmati Raas

Basmati Raas is a coed 16-person campus group that performs a traditional Indian folk dance known as Raas-Garba. With an unforgettable routine every year, we combine powerful moves, intricate costumes, and a colorful storyline. In addition to participating in various on-campus shows, conducting workshops in dorms, and performing at charity events in the community, we represent Stanford at various intercollegiate competitions throughout the country. Since 2003 Basmati Raas has placed at various competitions every year (see http://raas.stanford.edu for more details).

We would like to request increased funding to cover costumes, basic travel expenses, and accommodations to these intercollegiate competitions to face teams from Berkeley, UCLA, Duke, etc. We have been accepted into numerous competitions over the past few years, some of which we have had to turn down due to financial reasons. We continue to fundraise through other sources, but Special Fees every year serves as a lifeline for us in terms of funding. Please help us spread our passion for Raas-Garba and continue to represent Stanford at the highest level!

Application questions

Have you applied for Special Fees in the past 3 years? If so, please detail the outcome of each attempt.

Yes we applied for Special Fees two years ago and got the full amount we requested. This past year, we received approximately 85% of our requested amount.

How do you plan to publicize your events/programs to the greater Stanford community? Have you registered with Events at Stanford?

We widely publicize our on-campus events through paper fliers, e-fliers, Facebook event postings, and also advertise through academic departments. Since most of our on-campus events are collaborations with other groups/organizations (e.g. NSO O-Show, Rhythms, Cantor Party on the Edge, Sanskriti Mela, Parent's Weekend) they are heavily advertised and generally registered with Events at Stanford.

If you applied for Special Fees last year, is there an increase in the amount you're seeking this year? If so, why?

Yes. Airfare to competitions have significantly increased, and we have been invited to participate in a 4th, All-star competition.

Please define the services provided by your group with the Special Fee, as per the ASSU Constitution:

We request the Special Fee in order to primarily fund our travel to competitions where we represent Stanford nationally, alongside other college dance teams. On a deeper level, we also help preserve an ancient and traditional folkdance art form, which until recently was not known or performed outside of India. We share this aspect of a culture with the Stanford community as well as our performance attendees from across the country.

Please list all:1) assets, 2) reserves, 3) authorized and unauthorized non-ASSU bank accounts, 4) sources of funding other than Special

1) Funding from ASSU Undergrad Senate, The Stanford Fund, and performance fees (on-campus performances as well as competition prize money) 2) N/A 3) N/A 4) ASSU Undergrad Senate, The Stanford Fund, university departments, and performance fees

What are the three largest line item requests in your budget and why?

Our most expensive requests are travel fare to Boston, Miami and Detroit and accommodations at each of these locations.

What events/programs does your group hold throughout the year for the Stanford Community?

We are a regular and striking presence at NSO O-Show, Rhythms, Cantor Party on the Edge, Sanskriti Mela, and Parent's Weekend. We also host dorm study breaks at the end of each quarter; these are very successful events held at interested dorms during Study Week, during which we hold a dance workshop for any students, no background necessary.

What is the average attendance at your events?

On-campus, collaborative events: 200 attendees Off-campus competition events: 300 attendees

Why are you requesting Special Fees?

Because we are a competitive team, we travel several times per year. We regularly apply for funding from ASSU Undergrad Senate as well as The Stanford Fund, however the costs of airfare are not covered entirely by this funding, which we use primarily to fund costumes and stage props (airfare is often paid for out of team member dues). Thus, we would like to request Special Fees so that our team members may still enjoy competing as a team and representing Stanford without undergoing financial strain.

Miscellaneous information

Estimates and descriptions of planned expenses for the remainder of the current year

Airfare to Dallas, TX to compete ($220 X 16 = $3,520)
Accommodations at LA, Miami and Dallas ($1000 x 3 = $3000)
Registration Expense for Miami and Dallas ($450 x 2 = $900)

Reason for seeking undergrad-only Special Fees

We are seeking undergraduate fees because we are a group that primarily consists of undergraduates.

List of current assets (capital equipment, etc.)

Basmati Raas Dance Team Account (2800): $612.54

Sources of funding other than Special and General Fees, including but not limited to, alumni donations, corporate donations, grants, funding from other University units, endowment payouts

The Stanford Fund, performances

Current account statement












Application questions

Have you applied for Special Fees in the past 3 years? If so, please detail the outcome of each attempt.

We have applied for Special Fees for the past three years and have received the requested amount, or reasonably close, each time.

How do you plan to publicize your events/programs to the greater Stanford community? Have you registered with Events at Stanford?

We periodically hold events on campus where we show our car to members of the Stanford community. Every build cycle we flyer dorms to recruit new team members, and we park the car in White Plaza periodically in order to recruit students and sign them up to our mailing list.

If you applied for Special Fees last year, is there an increase in the amount you're seeking this year? If so, why?

A new opportunity has arisen which would allow us to not only be competitive in the 2011 World Solar Challenge, but win by a substantial margin. This involves the sponsorship of high-efficiency solar cells from a silicon valley startup. In order to fully exploit this unique opportunity, we need increased financial support from the ASSU and the greater Stanford Community.

Please define the services provided by your group with the Special Fee, as per the ASSU Constitution:

Solar Car provides Stanford students with a unique, hands-on engineering experience and educates members as general student body about the benefits and extraordinary potential of alternative energy technologies.

Please list all:1) assets, 2) reserves, 3) authorized and unauthorized non-ASSU bank accounts, 4) sources of funding other than Special

1) $13445.48 (includes a $20,000 check that should be deposited in our account in the coming days) 2) $0 3) Authorized ASSU bank accounts: 2-7848-1-0-2800 2-7848-1-0-2805 2-7848-1-0-9010 2-7848-2-5-7090 2-7848-2-5-7410 2-7848-9-0-2820 4) We maintain a comprehensive sponsorship and corporate relations program which generously covers most of the cost of our expenses which are not covered by Special Fees and the School of Engineering.

What are the three largest line item requests in your budget and why?

The largest line-item requests for our budget are a high-efficiency, high-performance solar array, molds and composites materials for creating the carbon-fiber body of our vehicle, and various electrical parts and equipment, including electric motors for propulsion. These items are crucial to our vehicle's development.

What events/programs does your group hold throughout the year for the Stanford Community?

Stanford Solar Car is very active throughout the Stanford community. In addition to our bi-weekly meetings (which are open to students of all sorts, ranging from science and engineering to humanities and liberal arts), we showcase our vehicles for a variety of engineering and clean-tech events which are held by the University. In addition, the solar car can often be found at Stanford alumni and prospective student events, as a great way to demonstrate the hands-on engineering experience Stanford provides.

What is the average attendance at your events?

We have approximately 50 members, and have an attendance of 20-25 members during our Monday and Saturday meetings

Why are you requesting Special Fees?

We are requesting Special Fees to help subsidize some of the costs of constructing our solar-powered race vehicle. We plan on winning the 2011 World Solar Challenge using high-efficiency, space-grade solar cells, potentially from a Bay Area startup. We hope to be the first American team to win the race in over 20 years.

Miscellaneous information

Estimates and descriptions of planned expenses for the remainder of the current year

  • a. Electronics - $5000
  • b. Composite Materials - $5000
  • c. NASC Entry Fee - $7500
  • d. Aerodynamic prototypes - $1000

Reason for seeking undergrad-only Special Fees

We're seeking undergraduate special fees due to the fact that the vast majority of our members are undergraduates at Stanford.

List of current assets (capital equipment, etc.)

Mill, Lathe, Band Saw, Punch, Break, Welders, Ford E-350 Van, Trailer, and 2 Solar Cars.

Sources of funding other than Special and General Fees, including but not limited to, alumni donations, corporate donations, grants, funding from other University units, endowment payouts

Alumni Donations, Corporate Donations, Grants, Funding from SoE and VPUE. We're expecting $25,000 from within the school (SOE, VPUE, etc) and $265,000 from corporate donations, grants, and small alumni donations.

fields.title: Justin R. Brown
fields.statement:
**The Big Idea
**
In a student group and need some money for an event? I can help you with that.
Is Stanford Administration giving you a hard time? I can help you with that.
Need a social life? I can help you with that.

Unlike some of the candidates running, I am not running because of a private interest from a student group. I am running to aid the interests of all graduate students.

**Experience**
I am a 4th year student in the Geophysics department. I have had an active role on the GSC since 2007 including:
Programming Chair (2007-2009)
Deputy Funding Committee Chair (2009-present)
Registrar's Student Advisory Board (2008-2009)
Earth Sciences GSC Rep. (2008-2009)
At-Large GSC Rep. (2009-present)

I look forward to working with the new GSC next year.

**Important**
It is also worth noting that it is not necessary to be elected to have significant influence on the GSC. Every graduate student is a member of the GSC. If you have an idea and want to execute a plan, let us know how we can help you succeed. 

**Non-elected Positions Open for 2010-2011**
Deputy Funding Committee Chair ($$$$, Decided by the Funding Committee)
2 Programming Chairs (responsible for large parties, Grad Formal, etc)
Secretary (responsible for meeting minutes, organizing agenda)
Food Czar (Organizes take-out for all GSC meetings)
Webmaster (self explanatory)
Parliamentarian (makes sure the GSC and Undergraduate Senate follow their bylaws)
Legislative Action Chair (Lobby in Sacramento and Washington, D.C. for Stanford Grad Issues)
Equipment Master (keeps track of and releases GSC equipment like speakers)
Publicity (gets the word out about GSC initiatives)
Grad Events Coordinator (sends weekly GSC email about graduate events)
Funding Committee Event Auditor (audits student groups throwing events with GSC money)

Most of these positions are paid.

Join our team. Get involved! It's a lot of fun.

P.S. For those of you who are single, it is worth noting that many individuals met their current spouse/partner on the GSC. Yup, that's right. GSC couples. Crazy huh?

fields.title: Kerensa Gimre
fields.statement:
**About me:**  I'm a graduate student in Civil and Environmental Engineering, concentrating in Atmosphere/Energy.  I performed my undergraduate work at Pacific University in Oregon, graduating in May of 2009.  I'm fascinated by absolutely everything and originally declared a double-major in Business and Journalism.  I soon saw the joy of History and believed my future job to be that of a modern-day Indiana Jones, so I switched my major.  I continued this major-changing-habit a total of seven times before settling on degrees in Math and Physics, with a minor in Environmental Science.  I racked up several credits along the way, and quickly relented on the Indiana Jones thing.  Besides, mathematics is soooo much cooler.  I'm now pursuing my Masters Degree here at Stanford, play in a piano trio (we're learning Beethoven's Archduke currently), enjoy hiking, coffee, reading, skiing, among with several other activities, and I'm probably the person who almost crashed her bike this morning.  :)

**My approach to the GSC:**  I come from an extremely small liberal arts college with less than 1500 undergraduates.  We had a (relatively) large graduate student population of roughly 2000, but the graduate population was not well-integrated into the campus as a whole.  Stanford's graduate population is similarly large in comparison to undergraduates, and I see a similar trend at Stanford; the undergraduates have a much more prominent role in the campus community, yet constitute a minority.  The involvement of the GSC on campus needs to grow.  Dramatically.   
In terms of approach to issues that may arise within the GSC (and within the larger Stanford community), I don't believe that any one person has the correct solution to any problem.  Rather, I prefer to reach solutions through an interdisciplinary approach that encompasses a broad range of interests to reach the most socially-optimal outcome.  Due to my varied interests and strengths, I believe I am an excellent candidate to promote the interests of students, yet still see the appropriate times to negotiate between divided factions.  I believe this makes me an effective and qualified leader for an active role in the GSC.

**Goals for next year:**  
1) Improve the transparency and visibility of the GSC.  The GSC is not an visibly active force on campus; it needs to expand its presence by pushing harder for important student causes and engaging in more events (NOT, however, by increasing spending).  See above.      
2) Improve collaboration with the Undergraduate Senate.  Most issues cannot be solved with just a portion of the student population.  They require a larger base in order to receive widespread support.                 
3) Improve events promoting careers after leaving the Stanford bubble.  Stanford has strong connections to companies in the Silicon Valley, and the GSC should take a more active role in promoting events that encourage students to look beyond their life at Stanford.           
4) Improve and increase multidisciplinary actions.  As stated earlier, I love interdisciplinary approaches.  Currently, most departments at Stanford work independently on similar problems, and I see huge potential for more collaboration.  This ties in with collaboration with the Undergraduate Senate.  See above.          
5) Improve involvement of students in the GSC.  Basically, inspire students to take a more active role in their educational experience outside the classroom.

fields.title: Jessica Tsai
fields.statement:
**About me:**
My name is Jess - I'm a 2nd year MD/PhD student in the Medical Scientist Training Program here at Stanford.  My PhD is in the Neuroscience Program.  I also did my undergrad here at Stanford and graduated in 2008.  I love neuroscience, running, cycling, and chocolate.  

**GSC:**
I am currently a voting member on the GSC as the Medicine Representative.  This past year, I also worked as the Programming co-Coordinator to bring you the 4th of July BBQ, the fall Back-to-School Party at Rains, and the upcoming Spring 2010 Graduate Formal which will be held at the Computer History Museum in Mountain View.  I have done a fair amount of work for Health Advocacy as well and also served on the Vaden Advisory Committee this year.  I welcome your input always and look forward to serving the graduate community here at Stanford.

fields.title: iThirteen
fields.statement:
**It’s Here, It’s Real, It’s Sexy. Introducing iThirteen.**

Hi, we’re iThirteen. We all know Stanford’s a great place and we’ve had a great freshman year, but iThirteen wants to make sophomore year even better. With iThirteen, you get the experience of three dorm presidents, the sensibility of Nelson Estrada, the creativity of Greg Naifeh, the spontaneity of Adam Klein, and the exuberance of Camilla Boyer, a combination that not only comes up with great ideas, but will actually get them done. Are you tired of having to choose between sweaty frats and lonely dorms to have some fun? Our platform includes fun on and off the row, complete with **Sophomore Concerts**, **Café Nights**, and an **iPhone App** filled with social calendars and event information. Our slate loves to play as much as you do, so let’s get to work.

**Work, meet Fun.**

After a week spent introducing yourself to the Humanities, it’s time to do the same with some more interesting members of your class. That’s where we come in. While crotch-to-butt introductions on the floor of Sigma Chi can be fun, iThirteen will allow you to actually talk to your fellow Thirteens and enjoy all that this great class has to offer. Our slate includes the founder of an event planning business, a nightclub promoter, and the lead of Gaieties, so if iThirteen looks like we want to have fun, it’s because we do, and we know how to make it happen. With unbelievable events such as **Tailgates**, a classed-up **Sophomore Formal**, and even a **Beach Day** already in the works, your weekends are sure to include much more fun and a lot less sweat than nights on the row. We will also bring the fun to you, with concerts and socials right on campus, complete with an **iPhone App** to always let you know where the party is.

**Beauty Outside, Beast Inside.**

Don’t be distracted by our sex appeal; each one of us has the tools necessary to get the job done. iThirteen brings a dynamic combination of personalities to the table, each one of which will make the Class of ’13 the best on the Farm. With the Programming Director of the Green Living Council, an International Public Service Ambassador, and the Event Chair of a hometown Relay for Life, it is clear that iThirteen has a strong commitment to public service. With events like **Cans for Cash** and our very own **“Give a Day (of service), Get a Day (of off campus adventures),”** we will make giving fun and rewarding. And if you are a long way from home, a student athlete, or can't afford the trip home over a break, our **Home Away from Home program** will feed you a delicious meal over the break. With a group like this, it’s hard to go wrong.

**iMagine the Possibilities.**

Making the best place in the world even better sounds tough, but iThirteen knows how to get there. Each one of your votes is one step closer to the best sophomore year you could imagine, and we love to have your support. iThirteen is here for you, and the sooner you vote, the sooner it’s yours.

**Platform Summary:**

* Sophomore Concerts
* Special Dinners with Faculty
* Class Socials: Tailgates and Tournaments
* Café Nights
* iThirteen iPhone App (with a social event calendar and more)
* Sick Class Gear
* Full Moon on the Quad (for real this time)
* Sophomore Formal
* Give a Day, Get a Day (a day of service for a day of off-campus adventures)
* Cans for Cash (bring in your cans and we give you cash)
* Sophomore Beach Day
* Home Away from Home (meals for students staying on campus over breaks)

fields.title: SIAS - Society for International Affairs at Stanford
fields.petition_budget_summary:
Sponsor: Victor Luong, lvluong@stanford.edu
Total request: $24,310.96
Requesting from: All undergraduates

You're signing a petition for Society for International Affairs at Stanford's (SIAS) Special Fee request. If approved, all students will pay a portion of this Special Fee on their University bill each quarter. Your signature indicates your support for this fee request and helps it get on the ballot for the ASSU Election on April 8–9. For SIAS's fee request to pass, it must obtain the signatures of 15% of all undergraduates and must get majority approval on the ballot. If this fee request fails to pass, SIAS will still receive $8,463 in Special Fees funding recommended for it by the Senate (if approved by voters).

The signature form is below the group's budget information.

Statement from Society for International Affairs at Stanford (SIAS)

SIAS seeks to provide students with high-quality programming geared towards international relations. This includes opportunities for students to get involved in serious international relations-focused debate competitions by joining Stanford's Model UN team. We also bring speakers and organize events on campus to address issues of international importance (e.g. conference on development in Papua New Guinea). We also bring Stanford undergrads the opportunity to organize a major Model UN conference for high school students. All our programming and participation at conferences are free to undergrads, thanks largely to Special Fees. Without this source of funding, SIAS cannot strive to be the campus center for international studies that it strives to be, especially compared to our peer institutions.

Application questions

See SIAS's full 2010-2011 app (requested amounts included; amounts for "Berkeley Model United Nations Conference" should be positive)

Have you applied for Special Fees in the past 3 years? If so, please detail the outcome of each attempt.

Yes, we were approved with modifications, then petitioned and was elected by the student body to the full amount. SIAS had the same financial officer for the last 3 years and I can contact him for more details.

If you applied for Special Fees last year, is there an increase in the amount you're seeking this year? If so, why?

Yes. We've made a push for expansion of the Model UN team this year, bringing an average of 5 more delegates to each conference. For example, whereas we've usually taken 18 - 20 delegates to the Yale conference in the past, we took 25 this past fall. By building on this year's expansion, Stanford is moving towards becoming on par with other top teams in the country (e.g. Yale, Harvard) with an average of 20 - 25 delegates at each competition. Part of the expansion is possible because of our ability to provide for travel, accomodations and registration expenses, allowing the delegates to travel for free. Furthermore, the high school conference is also expanding aggressively, with a projected attendance of 700, a 17% increase from last year. We're also expecting the conference to grow by 100 delegates each year for the next few years. Expansion means increased Marguerite rental fees, ABM janitorial fees, office supplies costs, more room, extra food for advisors and delegates.

Please define the services provided by your group with the Special Fee, as per the ASSU Constitution:

As a group, we seek to provide the Stanford Community with high quality programming that is geared towards international relations. This includes opportunities for students to get involved in serious foreign affairs competitions by joining Stanford's Model UN team. This includes bringing speakers to campus that address issues of international importance (nuclear proliferation, for example). This includes exposing to Model UN, and in this way to international relations, about 700 high school students from around the world (with many from the bay area) through our annual Model UN Conference (SMUNC). Organizing and running the conference is also a very valuable learning experience for Stanford undergraduates.

What are the three largest line item requests in your budget and why?

Our 3 largest items are, in order, Travel Fares, Accomodations and Registration Expenses for the UChicago conference. This is one of the nation's top conferences and certainly the highest-quality conference that we've attended. It is important for Stanford, as a nationally competitive team, to ensure that its members can afford to attend the Chicago conference in strength. Charging team members would discriminate against economically disadvantaged students.

What is the average attendance at your events?

For the Model UN team, we bring 15 - 25 students to each conference. We go to 4, 5 conferences/year. Our high school conference, SMUNC, is expected to have up to 700 delegates in attendance, supported by 60 - 70 undergraduates as staff. Our other events vary from 20 - 100, depending on the kind of events (e.g. policy lunch would have about 10 - 15, whereas the international development conference is expecting 50 - 100).

How do you plan to publicize your events/programs to the greater Stanford community? Have you registered with Events at Stanford?

We will flyer campus and send emails to all mailing lists that SIAS members have access to. SMUNC will be registered with Events at Stanford. Recruitment for SMUNC staff has already begun for the November conference.

Please list all:1) assets, 2) reserves, 3) authorized and unauthorized non-ASSU bank accounts, 4) sources of funding other than Special

1) Our main assets include a printer for SMUNC and a banner with "SIAS" printed on it. 2) 4, 955$ 3) We currently have 36, 906$ in our ASSU account (excluding reserves), although registration fees from our last conference and a few remaining reimbursements have not yet been claimed. There will also be additional expenses from our UChicago conference in the spring. We have no unauthorized non-ASSU accounts. 4) a. The Stanford Fund b. Stanford Model UN Conference.

What events/programs does your group hold throughout the year for the Stanford Community?

We hold an average of 3 events per quarter where we bring distinguished scholars to speak on issues of international relations and organize related events. For example, we're hosting a film screening, a policy lunch and co-sponsoring a conference on international development. We host Stanford's annual high school Model UN conference (SMUNC). Finally, we run Stanford Model UN Team which represents Stanford at 4-5 conferences each year.

Why are you requesting Special Fees?

We are requesting Special fees because we are committed to bring to the Stanford Community high quality events focused on international relations. First, we put on a high quality Stanford Model UN Conference (SMUNC) for high schoolers every year takes a lot of money. From room reservation fees, to printer supplies, to postcards, to food, and to the delegate social, we need the ability to fund that. Second, our community service and speaker's series require gas money, honoraria, room rental fees, etc. Third, we run Stanford's Model UN team, which by virtue of being a traveling team takes significant money to maintain. The best Model UN conferences are on the east coast and we have to pay for 20+ people's flights, accomodations, registration fees, and so forth.

Miscellaneous information

Estimates and descriptions of planned expenses for the remainder of the current year

Postage/Courier: postcards to high schools for next Stanford Model UN Conference: 124.46$
Facilities Rental: rental space for SIAS events spring quarter: 750$
Travel Fares: flights to UChicago conference in April: 6480$
Accomodations: UChicago conference lodgings: 2235$
Registration Expenses(reimbursement for Yale & UChicago registration expenses): 4440$

Reason for seeking undergrad-only Special Fees

Undergrad: we are an all-undergrad organization.

List of current assets (capital equipment, etc.)

One printer for Stanford Model United Nations Conference.

Sources of funding other than Special and General Fees, including but not limited to, alumni donations, corporate donations, grants, funding from other University units, endowment payouts

We work with The Stanford Fund all three quarters of the year.

fields.petition_budget_summary:
Sponsor: Maria Carolina Roeller, roeller@stanford.edu
Total request: $76,692
Requesting from: Undergrads & graduate students

You're signing a petition for Sunday FLiCKS' Special Fee request. If approved, all students will pay a portion of this Special Fee on their University bill each quarter. Your signature indicates your support for this fee request and helps it get on the ballot for the ASSU Election on April 8–9. For FLiCKS' fee request to pass, it must obtain the signatures of 15% of all students and must get majority approval on the ballot. If this fee request fails to pass, FLiCKS will still receive $67,742 in Special Fees funding recommended for it by the Undergrad Senate and Grad Student Council (if approved by voters).

The signature form is below the group's budget information.

Statement from FLiCKS

Dear Stanford Community,

The budget for Sunday FLiCKS has recently been cut 20% by the Stanford Appropriations Committee, eliminating most FLiCKS staff positions and some equipment. Although we recognize and accept the current budget situation, we also know that FLiCKS cannot be sustained past this year on this budget. FLiCKS has offered to take a voluntary budget cut of 8% for next year, but we will need 2298 signatures by March 5 to get on the Special Fees ballot.

If you have enjoyed FLiCKS showings in the past, and would like to see this hundred-year-old Stanford tradition continue, we sincerely ask you to sign this petition, and help keep FLiCKS alive and well.

Sincerely,
The FLiCKS Management

fields.title: The No-Rain Campaign
fields.statement:
We propose simple ways to fix campus problems, like having an ASSU website listing the ISBN's of the textbooks you'll use in your classes. We're unhappy with the ASSU's out-of-control spending, so we're not spending anything on our campaign. We avoid empty promises. We're experienced and we're [qualified](http://www.stanford.edu/~dleifer/norain/about.html).

Visit our [website](http://stanford.edu/~dleifer/norain), watch our videos, and spread the word!

fields.title: Salvador Zepeda
fields.statement:
**Goals**

My goal is to **represent the interest of the Stanford community** in the GSC. I will be active in proposing, supporting and challenging the ideas that impact our community. My priorities are:

1. Building a **stronger sense of community** involving all graduate schools

2. Promoting respect, fairness, and diversity

3. Exploring new programs that would make **student life easier** (e.g. personal support in declaring taxes) 

**Contribution**

I believe I am a good candidate because **I can bring a diverse outlook** to the GSC:

1. I am originally from Mexico, and I lived one year in Sub-Saharan Africa and another year in the Middle East

2. I have worked in 6 different countries

3. I belong to two schools, Engineering and Humanities & Sciences, because I am pursuing a joint degree in MS&E and MPP

4. I led community activities in very different settings: I founded the Analyst Community in McKinsey’s Dubai Office and led a Industrial Engineering Association in my university in Mexico

My life experiences provide me with a unique perspective and new ideas from very different places. Nonetheless, I still need to learn more about the Stanford community to serve it well. If elected, I will strive to get to know your needs better and represent your interests in the best way.

fields.title: Peacock and Bakke
fields.statement:
**Our Mission:**
We are the first all grad slate running in the history of ASSU Exec, and are committed to the fact that grad students can and will serve the entire Stanford student community. With extensive experience in both undergraduate and graduate student government and the right connections with the administration here at Stanford, we have the background necessary to tackle the issues you care about most.

[Endorsed by The Stanford Review](http://stanfordreview.org/article/for-executive-peacockbakke)

See our [profile](http://www.stanforddaily.com/2010/04/05/assu-executive-peacock-and-bakke/) and [guest column](http://www.stanforddaily.com/2010/04/05/peacock-and-bakke-executive-slate-ryan-peacock-and-jonathan-bakke/) in the Stanford Daily.

[P and B on Facebook](http://www.facebook.com/photo.php?pid=31098720&id=1398116914#!/pages/Peacock-and-Bakke-for-ASSU-Exec/377141184487?ref=ts)

[Beat That!](http://www.stanford.edu/~rpeacock/PB_flyer_1_color.pdf)  


**What we stand for:**

* Increase financial and ethical accountability of Exec and broader ASSU
    * Evaluate all ASSU programs and hold them to tangible goals
    * Increase transparency of the ASSU
    * Work to improve outreach to the student body as a whole
* Smarter spending
    * Cut Executive stipends in half
    * Streamlining and reduction of the size of the cabinet
    * Use discretionary funds to help VSOs accomplish goals instead of duplicating their efforts
* Focus on what matters
    * Issues that affect day to day life of Stanford students like academic advising, VSO funding, and social programming
    * Increase dialogue and improve relationships with the administration
    * Ending the practice of wasteful spending on pet projects
* Improve the overall long term sustainability of the ASSU


**Leadership and Bio Highlights:**

Peacock  
Fourth year PhD student  
2010 GSC Financial Officer  
2009 GSC Representative  
2006 College President at Rice University in Houston

Bakke  
Fourth year PhD student  
2010 ASSU Nominations Commission Chair  
2008, 2009 Committee for Research Student Rep  
2005, 2006 Engineering Student Council President and Honor Board Chair at Tulane University in New Orleans

You're signing a petition for Students for a Sustainable Stanford's (SSS) Special Fee request. If approved, all students will pay a portion of this Special Fee on their University bill each quarter. Your signature indicates your support for this fee request and helps it get on the ballot for the ASSU Election on April 8–9. For SSS's fee request to pass, it must obtain the signatures of 10% of all undergrads and must get majority approval on the ballot. If this fee request fails to pass, SSS will still be eligible for $6,000 in ASSU General Fees funding.

The signature form is below the group's budget information.

Statement from Students for a Sustainable Stanford (SSS)

Students for a Sustainable Stanford (SSS) works to ensure that environmental sustainability is a core principle behind social, structural, and educational development in our community. We execute and support initiatives to broker a harmonious relationship between the University and its ecosystem.

SSS's operational structure consists of four subgroups that initiate direct projects with the university on the issues of food, energy, water, and the resource stream. We also have an outreach team that engages with on and off campus stakeholders to provide student integration for related or parallel projects and initiatives. We are applying for special fees this year to reduce the burden of securing funding for direct projects, co-sponsored and initiated events such as the Social-Movement Challenge, and the operational costs of our largest event "FutureFest," a collaborative event with SOCA, SCN, and the Green Alliance for Innovative Action (GAIA). Our application reflects an investment in sustainability as a core value of the university and recognizes Stanford students as key actors in realizing this commitment.

Have you applied for Special Fees in the past 3 years? If so, please detail the outcome of each attempt.

How do you plan to publicize your events/programs to the greater Stanford community? Have you registered with Events at Stanford?

We want to engage in creative advertising rather than simple fliers. This includes art, videos, exhibitions, social movements, etc.

If you are an umbrella group, please list the groups for which you are applying for Special Fees, their ASSU account numbers, and contact information for their financial officers.

We do our best to bring sustainability to campus in many facets, in taking actions on campus, in bringing engagement to students, and in providing people with an easy facet to learn about issues.

What are the three largest line item requests in your budget and why?

Equipmental Rental - Needed to transform White Plaza and give people the opportunity to engage and explore issues. Event Supplies - Needed for a variety of groups to complete their imagination in reaching out to students and in creating creative and engaging booths and exhibits. Equipment Purchase - This to support SSS' own work in their subgroups. The explanation is in the line item.

What events/programs does your group hold throughout the year for the Stanford Community?

We have a variety of outreach programs like composting awareness and climate talks. Also, we work with the University to discuss the University's own actions. Also, we work a lot with the campus to take actions like the Water Catchment project, Kitchen Manager ordering strategies, fertilizer.

What is the average attendance at your events?

This year we are expecting FutureFest to have at least a couple hundred attendees, potentially more depending on the concert. Other awareness events have around 30-60 people.

Why are you requesting Special Fees?

We are requesting Special Fees to allow FutureFest to be an established, substantial, and institutionalized event. Next year will be the third year that FutureFest will take place in a large fashion. The previous two years, SSS has collaborated with almost a dozen other student groups like SoCA, GAIA, SCN, STOP, NAACP, Energy Crossroads, FUSION, and BASES. SSS would like to organize this event, but definitely include the collaboration and support to hold an annual great event covering the issues that face us in the future. Our application for special fees reaffirms us as an umbrella group that brings people together to take substantial action. This money will go in a large part to other groups to help with putting on the event.

fields.statement:
Hello! Thanks for considering Students for a Sustainable Stanford.

We are requesting Special Fees for the first time this year due to our role as the umbrella group helping organize FutureFest. Next year, we seek to continue the great work that's being done in attracting a wide range of student groups like ASSU, SoCA, GAIA, SCN, STOP, NAACP, Energy
Crossroads, FUSION, and BASES. Similar to this year, it will a substantial event that reaches out widely across campus to bring people together for both fun and important issues of the day.

SSS is helping organize the collaboration and support to hold this annual great event. Our application for special fees reaffirms us as an umbrella group that brings people together to take
substantial action. This money will go in a large part to other groups to contribute to the event to gather a wide range of viewpoints and participation.

The choice to apply for Special Fees stemmed from FutureFest, but SSS has been doing great events within its group for the past few years. We were awarded the Dean's award last year for Outstanding VSO. We've helped push Stanford to be active in its climate plan, built a rain catchment system, collaborated with school departments on new fertilizer techniques, and worked with Row kitchen managers.

fields.petition_budget_summary:

Requesting from: All undergrads

You're signing a petition for The Bridge's Special Fee request. If approved, all students will pay a portion of this Special Fee on their University bill each quarter. Your signature indicates your support for this fee request and helps it get on the ballot for the ASSU Election on April 8–9. For The Bridge's fee request to pass, it must obtain the signatures of 15% of all undergrads and must get majority approval on the ballot. If this fee request fails to pass, The Bridge will still be eligible for $4,691 in ASSU Special Fees funding (if approved by voters).

The signature form is below the group's budget information.

Statement from The Bridge

Established in 1971, The Bridge Peer Counseling Center is a twenty-four hour a day, seven day a week peer counseling resource for the Stanford community. Staffed around the clock by trained and dedicated Stanford students, the Bridge provides free, anonymous, and confidential services to Stanford students, ensuring that they have a place to talk about any issues at any time. The Bridge has offered invaluable services to many students over the years, on issues including, but not limited to, depression, anxiety, sexuality, disordered eating, and relationships. We are proud of the trust which students place in us to assist them in coping with the stressors of lift at Stanford. The counseling statistics speak to the rate of utilization of our services on campus. In addition, senior Bridge staffers have been involved in a wide variety of student mental and sexual health ventures across campus, including the Alcohol Advisory Board, Sexual Violence Advisory Board, Mental Health and Well Being Task Force, Mirror, Stanford Peace of Mind, Sexual Health Peer Resource Center, in addition to many other panels and workshops.

Finally, Bridge staffers are heavily involved in the administration of EDUC 193A and 193P, background courses in peer counseling, which are available to students with interest in working as peer service providers on the Stanford campus.

Have you applied for Special Fees in the past 3 years? If so, please detail the outcome of each attempt.

How do you plan to publicize your events/programs to the greater Stanford community? Have you registered with Events at Stanford?

We also are asking for more funding for the water bottles, as the number we purchased last year weren't sufficient for campus-wide new student coverage.

Please define the services provided by your group with the Special Fee, as per the ASSU Constitution:

Established in 1971, The Bridge Peer Counseling Center is a twenty-four hour a day, seven day a week peer counseling resource for the Stanford community. Staffed around the clock by trained and dedicated Stanford students, the Bridge provides free, anonymous, and confidential services to Stanford students, ensuring that they have a place to talk about any issues at any time. The Bridge has offered invaluable services to many students over the years, on issues including, but not limited to, depression, anxiety, sexuality, disordered eating, and relationships. We are proud of the trust which students place in us to assist them in coping with the stressors of lift at Stanford. The counseling statistics speak to the rate of utilization of our services on campus. In addition, senior Bridge staffers have been involved in a wide variety of student mental and sexual health ventures across campus, including the Alcohol Advisory Board, Sexual Violence Advisory Board, Mental Health and Well Being Task Force, Mirror, Stanford Peace of Mind, Sexual Health Peer Resource Center, in addition to many other panels and workshops.

Finally, Bridge staffers are heavily involved in the administration of EDUC 193A and 193P, background courses in peer counseling, which are available to students with interest in working as peer service providers on the Stanford campus.

Please list all:1) assets, 2) reserves, 3) authorized and unauthorized non-ASSU bank accounts, 4) sources of funding other than Special

1) $11,592.14
2) $7,559.72
3) 2800 THE BRIDGE : $8.10
2830 THE STANFORD FUND $466.69
SPECIAL FEES
4) N/A (Stanford Fund discontinued as of this year)

What are the three largest line item requests in your budget and why?

$4700 - Marketing expenses for the 2000 water bottles that we distribute to freshmen and new graduate students at the start of every academic year to make them aware of the Bridge as a resource.
$3310 - Phone bill for the 24 hour phone service at the Bridge
$1005 - programming expenses for the various events that the Bridge puts on through out the year. This includes specific marketing for events, event details and event specific equipment

What events/programs does your group hold throughout the year for the Stanford Community?

None, as the Bridge does not hold events "per se." Please see the question below for a listing of direct and indirect services provided to the Stanford community.

What is the average attendance at your events?

Bridge Only sponsered events have between a 20-100 participants. The Bridge also co-sponsers events with Vaden Health Center, SHPRC and ASSU Executive Health and Wellness which have similar attendance or are campus wide promotional events. Number of counsels are listed in the following table:

       Winter Spring Summer Fall
2004   87     65     16     44
2005   52     37     15     68
2006   58     66     25     76
2007   97     61     28     90
2008   67     93     12     81
2009   71     86     14     84

Why are you requesting Special Fees?

To fund our phone bills for the 24 hour phone counseling service at the Bridge. We also need funds to continuously market ourselves as a Peer Resources Center for the continued wellness of the Stanford community.>

Miscellaneous information

View The Bridge's full Special Fees application for next year (2010-2011)


Estimates and descriptions of planned expenses for the remainder of the current year

$400 – Renovation of a counsel room in the Bridge in order to make it more welcoming for students seeking help.
$1900 – Phone bills for the remainder of the year.
$70 – Art project supplies for Spring EDUC193A classes
$200 – Programming costs for Spring Quarter
$100 – Salary for student who designed the Bridge website

Reason for seeking undergrad-only Special Fees

Undergrad Special Fees because our membership is primarily undergraduate, though we do provide services to both undergraduates and graduates.

List of current assets (capital equipment, etc.)

Computer at Rogers House (the Bridge) for logging counsels
Art Project making material for EDUC193A section projects
Miscellaneous Office Supplies
General Bridge fliers

Sources of funding other than Special and General Fees, including but not limited to, alumni donations, corporate donations, grants, funding from other University units, endowment payouts

No other source of funding. We used to receive funding from The Stanford Fund, but it has been stopped this year.

fields.title: Erik Lehnert
fields.statement:
**Bio-Sketch**  
I'm a third-year PhD candidate in the Genetics Department.  I did my undergrad here at Stanford as well, graduating in '07 with a degree Biological Sciences (as it was known back then).  In my free time I like to garden, hang out in San Francisco, and brew my own beer/wine.

**Qualifications**

1)  I've been here seven years (counting undergrad).  During that time, besides being a student, I've been a TA, on dorm staff, a course planner, and president of a ~300 person group (GradQ, Stanford's LGBT graduate student group).  I've also coordinated with my department admins to improve biosciences diversity outreach programs to make them include a broader spectrum of diversity.  Basically, I've taught courses, handled large budgets, and been responsible for feeding 55 people.  Everyone passed, money was spent responsibly, and no one starved.

2)  I work well with people from a lot of different communities.  In the last three years, I've worked with everyone from faculty, LGBT students and staff, department administrators, Iraq war veterans applying for college, a Republican congressman, and current GSC members.

3)  Most importantly, I take what I do seriously and genuinely want to make Stanford a better place.  While I think we have it pretty good here on the Farm, it takes committed people working hard to keep things running smoothly, fix the problems that pop up, and make sure people have fun.  I'm willing to do that, even if it means sitting through GSC meetings for a year.  :)  

  
**GSC Goals**  

1)  Help student groups get funding/plan events.  I've been working with a student organization for three years now, and there is still a lot about how group funding works that confuses me.  Funding is pretty straight-forward only once you know how to do it; I want to make the process more transparent so student groups (especially new ones where there isn't institutional memory for how to do this sort of thing) can get a fair share of the money their members paid into the system.

2)  Help with diversity.  I've been working with GradQ for a couple of years now, a large part of which has been talking to the biosciences departments about how to improve diversity events during interview weekend.  I'd like to help find ways to help departments and student groups work together better, because other students are the best sources for information about what it's like to be part of a particular demographic at Stanford - whether it's racial/ethnic minority, raising kids as a grad student, or finding a religious community you're comfortable with.  The undergrads do this really well - why don't we?  I'd also like to start seeing more events that bring together different populations within Stanford, because diversity doesn't just mean representation.  It means getting people from different groups and backgrounds mixing and making friends.  See below.

3)  Help throw good parties.  I've helped set up parties, both for my undergrad dorm and as a grad student.  I don't mind moving things for set-up, and I pour beer well.

fields.title: Krystal St. Julien
fields.statement:
**About Me:**  I'm a second year grad student in the Department of Biochemistry in the School of Medicine.  I study lung development and disease with the hopes of someday translating relevant biological knowledge into medical advances.  In addition to my role as a student of science, I am highly active in the Stanford community.  This year alone I have become a representative for the Biomedical Association for the Interest of Minority Students (BioAIMS), outreach coordinator and emcee for the Stanford Comedy Club, the newest board member of the Grad Student Programming Board (GSPB), a member of the GSC funding committee, and, most important, a regularly attending member of the GSC.  

**My Goals:**  
1) Work with SSE and the Undergraduate Senate to make all funding policies and banking rules much more transparent to Stanford's volunteer student organizations (VSOs) as well as the stanford community as a whole. 

2) Promote collaboration between branches of student government to eliminate redundancies in the roles of the GSC, Undergraduate Senate, and ASSU Executive.

3) Use my knowledge of VSOs to help develop strategies to get like-minded and different-minded groups to collaborate with one another and promote new cross-sectional events enjoyable by all graduate students.
 
**Moving Forward:**  The GSC is in an interesting place right now.  Not everyone may know that the GSC is a relatively new faction of Stanford's student government.  Next year will be the first year that none of the original founders of this group are active.  Therefore, I think it is crucial at this time that the newest voted members of the GSC be borne with the confidence, foresight, and know-how to keep things running smoothly as well as be able to make steps forward.  I have taken this past year to familiarize myself with all things GSC, including being deputized with the responsibilities of funding committee chair for the upcoming year, and I am looking forward to performing as a full representative for the graduate student community.

fields.title: Bennett Siegel
fields.statement:
My name is Bennett Siegel and I am running for the ASSU Senate. I get that most students are apathetic about student government at Stanford, but what I do know is that everyone cares about enhancing the quality of the Stanford experience.

I believe that the ASSU first and foremost is an institution designed to address student issues on campus. Whether it is focusing on student wellness, social outreach or appropriating funds to group, the Senate’s main responsibility is to work on improving the lives of those they were elected to represent. In past few years a credibility crisis has emerged within the ASSU. The Senate must reconnect with the undergraduate community in order serve its proper function. There needs to be more transparency and accountability, more engagement and integration of student input and more initiatives to tackle the everyday problems of students. In that vein, my platform focuses on concrete matters that affect us all.

1. Increased Student Advocacy and Engagement
2. Flexible and Responsible Student Group Funding
3. Reform Student Activities and Leadership (SAL) for Party Planning
4. Community Action to Promote Mental Health, Wellness, and Diversity
5. Continue Work on Environmental Sustainability
6. Improve Academic Advising

For a much more detailed look at my platform and goals, please visit my facebook page at http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=352080920278&ref=ts. Fundamentally, I want every student to recognize that they are a shareholder in the ASSU and have a stake in the system. I am running, because I believe we together can help make this University a better place.

Your signature indicates your support for this fee request and helps it get on the ballot for the ASSU Election on April 8–9. For Stanford Chaparral's fee request to pass, it must obtain the signatures of 15% of all undergrads and must get majority approval on the ballot. Have you applied for Special Fees in the past 3 years? If so, please detail the outcome of each attempt.

Every one of the past three years we have campaigned successfully for Special Fees. In 2007, we requested $20,100 and were recommended for that amount by the Senate. In 2008, we campaigned for $21,510 and were approved for the same amount. Last year, we requested $21,825 and were recommended for that amount.

How do you plan to publicize your events/programs to the greater Stanford community? Have you registered with Events at Stanford?

Our weekly meetings are publicized in the magazine and online, and any other events would be publicized through flyering, social networking, and in the magazine itself.

If you applied for Special Fees last year, is there an increase in the amount you're seeking this year? If so, why?

We are requesting an increase of $445 this year, fully commensurate with inflation and in order to possibly publish an extra issue. This increase is also in line with increases in our budget over the past several years.

Please define the services provided by your group with the Special Fee, as per the ASSU Constitution:

With the funding provided by the Special Fee, the Stanford Chaparral publishes six issues of the glossy Chaparral Magazine each year. The Chaparral is the primary humor magazine of the Stanford students and Stanford University, and the second-oldest college humor magazine in the United States.

Please list all:1) assets, 2) reserves, 3) authorized and unauthorized non-ASSU bank accounts, 4) sources of funding other than Special

1) Assets: 23,641.53 2) Reserves (included in assets): 4,075.14 3) Non-ASSU bank accounts: None 4) Non-Special Fee sources of funding: Alumni Donations, Fundraising (Stanford Fund).

What are the three largest line item requests in your budget and why?

The three largest line item requests in our budget are (1) the request for the cost of the publication of the Parody Issue, our only full-color issue of the year, (2) our request for the cost of the publication of the Fall Issue, our largest issue of the year, and (3) the request for the cost of the publication of the Freshman Issue, our most important issue of the year in establishing our presence on campus and recruiting new talent to the magazine. We publish around four thousand copies of each issue in order to distribute to a large portion of the Stanford student body and to serve our large body of alumni and other off-campus subscribers.

What events/programs does your group hold throughout the year for the Stanford Community?

In the past the Chaparral has tried to bring a celebrity comedian or stand-up comic to campus for the presentation of the "Golden Hammer," our highest award. Though we have not done this in the past two years, we look forward to bestowing the award on a worthy comedic voice sometime in the near future, perhaps next year. On a smaller scale, our weekly meetings are open to one and all, provide an opportunity for discussion and the development of ideas, and often actively engage portions of the Stanford student body that would not otherwise come into contact with the Chaparral.

What is the average attendance at your events?

For our weekly brainstorming and layout meetings we usually have between fifteen and twenty-five people in attendance.

Why are you requesting Special Fees?

To enable the Chaparral to continue publishing the magazine at six issues a year.

Miscellaneous information

Estimates and descriptions of planned expenses for the remainder of the current year

As seen on current year budget.

Reason for seeking undergrad-only Special Fees

We will be seeking Undergraduate Special Fees. The Chaparral is an undergraduate humor magazine that primary serves the undergraduate student body with six glossy issues a year.

List of current assets (capital equipment, etc.)

Our assets include approximately $7,500 worth of computers and $4,075.14 in reserves.

Sources of funding other than Special and General Fees, including but not limited to, alumni donations, corporate donations, grants, funding from other University units, endowment payouts

STANFORD FUND: $2500
ALUMNI DONATIONS: $5000
