fields.title: Joanna Lankester
fields.statement:
Hi! I'm Joanna. I've probably handed you a beer at a grad party or a burger at a campus BBQ at some point since I've been involved in planning lots of grad social events. If not, I hope to meet you at an event soon! 


**Goals as a GSC representative:**

As a GSC representative I would strive to do much of what my goal has been as a grad residence Community Associate: **_to reach students from a diverse range of backgrounds and experiences, providing them with the resources they need and opportunities to meet each other_**. Serving as a GSC representative would be an additional opportunity to represent you and effect change! As your representative, I would welcome your suggestions on campus policies, students needs, or fun events you'd like to attend. 


With GSC I'm especially interested in working on: healthcare and wellness, housing, transportation, resources for grad students with families, and of course, social events. 


**Experience:**

On campus I've been involved with the CA program in Rains and Lyman, Women in Electrical Engineering (WEE), the Wellness Room Project, and the social dance scene. **_Events I've run have included a wide range of interests_** such as hiking, speed dating, night out at the Nuthouse, knitting, parties, dances, volunteer activities, and approximately three million free food events. I've worked with enough people around campus that I have a pretty good idea of **_resources available to help grad students make life easier_**. 


**Details, details:**

I'm a 4th-year Ph.D. student in Electrical Engineering. Don't worry, I'm not graduating anytime soon.

fields.title: Fanuel Muindi
fields.statement:
**Short Bio**
My name is Fanuel Muindi. I am a 2nd Year PhD student in the department of biology here at Stanford. I am from a beautiful country in East Africa called Tanzania. I have spent a considerable chunk of my life in the United Kingdom and I am racking up some serious time across coasts here in the United States.  

**Involvement in the GSC**
I have been an active member of the Diversity Advocacy Committee (DAC) since beginning my Stanford journey. Briefly, the committee strives to increase and support diversity here at Stanford, among undergraduates, graduate students, and faculty. Our main event each year (Diversity Week) allows for discussion between students, faculty members and administrators on several diversity related issues ranging from what Stanford is doing to support diversity across campus to addressing some of the general concerns that students have. Additionally, invited speakers also share their expertise on the importance of diversity in higher education. I plan to continue championing the committee’s cause and also support other groups on campus that seek to promote an understanding on the importance of diversity. I see it as a must that Stanford leads the way in sending out leaders that will be a voice for those whose voices are never heard.

fields.title: Addy Satija
fields.statement:
Another Grad Student looking for a job in [this](http://money.cnn.com/2010/04/01/news/economy/challenger_job_cuts/index.htm?hpt=T2) economy as your Representative.

__Qualifications and Experience__:

1. **Has organised events**: As _EV CA_, I organised Meet Thy Neighbour socials for my building almost every week. Also, I organised events in San Francisco for the entire Escondido Village community. This year, I was promoted to _Head CA_ and _Chair of EdCult_ - the people who take you out to the Ballet, the Movies, the Theatre and the Opera!

2. **Has thrown parties (Has schlepped)**: As the _GSC Programming Chair_, I organised many all-school parties and that includes the upcoming [Grad Formal](http://gsc.stanford.edu/formal/). As an _Electrical Engg Social Organiser_, I have organised HappEE Hours that generated _zero landfill trash_! In my dual capacity as GSC Representative and CA, I have personally volunteered my services from flyering to bar-tending to firing-grills to flipping-burgers to cleaning-up at graduate events. You've seen me pump kegs, dump ice pails and bring in the Recycling Bins! 

3. **Has managed money**:As the _GSC Funding Committee Chair_, I have administered disbursal of $205,000 to student groups and organisations for holding campus-wide events. I have pioneered a system to collect feedback and used that to change funding policies during the year. I have also instituted tight collaboration between the Graduate Events funding procedure with the Graduate Events publicity system. 

4. **Has fought for your interests**: As a member of the _Stanford Dining Committee_, I have represented the interests of my peers and have helped in the effective evolution of the _Graduate Meal Plan_ and the on-line menu system. I helped getting international students a better deal from Vaden when they made _Cardinal Care_ mandatory for us. I also ran the _Graduate Student Information Centre_ for new graduate students this year.

__Plans for the job__: 

1. At the School of Engineering, the lack of Gender Diversity is a severe problem and if elected, I intend to work with the University towards a fair and effective solution. 

2. I have also had the opportunity to identify many improvements that we can make in graduate event funding and publicity. I am already working in that direction. If re-elected, I intend to continue focusing my efforts towards these goals. 

3. I intend to continue providing a forceful voice to the interests of Masters students and international students in areas like Housing, Health-care and Alumni-relations at all relevant fora in addition to representing the larger interests of the Graduate Student body.

__How to hire?__: 

If you have a valid SUNet ID, please be sure to log on to http://ballot.stanford.edu at any time on Friday Apr 9, 2010 and vote for ADDY SATIJA as an At-large Representative. 

The At-large votes count...make your vote count for me!

fields.title: Crystal Yin
fields.statement:
**Email**
    crystaly@stanford.edu
**Candidate statement**
Help you find a job, enjoy your life at Stanford and get exposed to different cultures

**About me:**
I am pursuing a master’s degree in Management Science and Engineering. I was born in China and have completed my undergraduate degree in Food Science and Technology in National University of Singapore. I have been working in GSC since the time I came to Stanford, and have been really enjoying it. In addition, I identified the areas that I hope to work on: 
1)	Career Opportunities; 
2)	Easier life with Fun;
3)	Inter-culture/ discipline interactions; 
4)	International Students

** Experiences:**

  **1. Participated in GSC:**
I have participated in every single GSC meeting since 2009 Sep, as the secretary and many times proxy for voting members. Throughout this year, I understand how GSC operates and identified the things that I hope to work on. 

  **2. Organized Events:**
As the Vice President for Career Development for ACSSS, and CFO for Chinese Entrepreneur Organization at Stanford, I have been organizing numerous Talks by Entrepreneurs¸ Career Workshops for international students, Workshops & Panel Discussions for Academia Matters. These events have benefited the graduate student community as a whole.       
       
**Goals:**


**1. More Career Opportunities and Skill Development**
I will work with Career Development Center to provide graduate students with more opportunities, guidance and resources, for both students who want to advance in academia as well as those who want to go to industry. Internship postings should be greatly increased. I will work with VPGE to provide workshops helping graduate students on specific skills like relationships with their advisors, thesis writing, networking, etc.

**2. Easier Life and More Parties**
I will advocate for graduate students to get more convenience in terms of everyday dining, transportation, living and social life. More parties, with lots of fun and connection opportunities, will be thrown out. 

**3. Promote inter-culture and inter-discipline interactions**
Many student organizations at Stanford are organizing great events that promoting their own culture, however on these events, not many people from other cultures are present. I will work on the inter-culture exposure and collaboration to enhance the experience of all the Stanford graduate students. In addition, I will work on the inter-discipline interactions by organizing targeted events.

**4. Firm representatives for international, female and master students**
While representing the interests of the entire graduate students as a GSC at-large member, I also wish to be a firm representative of many important minority groups such as international students, female students and Master students in important areas such as Health-care, Immigration, and Alumni-relations.







**Vote for me!**

Anybody with a valid SUNet ID can vote! Please simple log on to http://ballot.stanford.edu at any time on Friday Apr 9, 2010 and vote for Crystal Yin as the as the At-large Representative.

fields.title: Ai Chloe Chien
fields.statement:
Chloe Chien is a second-year taking a year off because she is really enthusiastic about leading SMSA. Her strengths and interests are improving student services, organizing events, spearheading new projects, building relationships with University administration, keeping up with all-campus developments and sharing resources with the SMS student body. She has previously served on the SMSA as the Chair of Communications Committee and a Social Chair. Her committees have brought to you the Campus Event Calendar, Grand Rounds Calendar, Quarterly Deans' Town Halls, Med Student Research Database, Medipedia updates, Student Group Portal, Interesting Electives Databse, etc, and various SMS-wide events like Annual Tahoe Retreat, Winter Carnival, SMS movie nights, UCSF-Stanford Yosemite Retreat, and more!

Oh, and Chloe loves talking about herself in 3rd person. She will keep speaking this way until she is elected.

fields.title: Nico Grundmann
fields.statement: Stepping down from the social chair position, but I figure that our socially-restricted 3rd year selves are still going to want and break lose every now and then...

fields.title: Tao Chu
fields.statement:
About me:

I am a first year graduate student in Electrical Engineering here at Stanford. Someone like me is considered a 1.5th generation immigrant because I immigrated along with my parents during my youth. My uniqueness is my exposure to two cultures, passion for life, and compassion to help those around me. My upbringing allowed me to appreciate many cultures outside my own and initiated my service to the international community: In my high school and undergraduate studies I took active roles as core members in the student organizations which promoted cultural awareness. I sincerely believe I can serve as a bridge helping to close gaps among people, organizations, and cultures to meet the needs of people of all cultural backgrounds. Academically I am trained in both engineering and economics. As a pragmatist, I appreciate technology yet I find it more satisfying when people are directly benefiting from the tools we invent. For these reasons I consider myself an appropriate candidate to represent the school of engineering in the GSC where international students are underrepresented.


The Goals:

As the engineering representative in GSC, I plan to continue what I do and bring over my experience from ACSSS: help international and domestic students with their transition to the Stanford community, defend their rights (e.g. health care, dependent benefits), fund events that promote cultural understanding, promote interdisciplinary events (e.g. engineering and business, the D-school), social events that increase faculty and student interaction, and career events that connect Stanford to establishments in the Silicon Valley.

fields.title: jake rosenberg
fields.statement:
I'm running for CCAP Rep to help guide a productive discussion on how we want our curriculum to evolve. This coming year, a number of important issues are going to be discussed that will affect our education and the future of SMS: CBEI will go into implementation, a rethink of the first quarters of the curriculum is in the works, and there will be an attempt to better organize and map specific content of courses.
  Through all this, my key priority is that we as a student body discuss these issues, come up with consensus opinions, and early on and productively work with administration to add our voice to the decision making process.
  My other key priority is that we need to have a tighter more tuned link between direct student feedback and adjustment in curriculum. We need to work to improve tools for evaluation and suggestion so that on the lecture, professor, and course level, we are able to submit specific feedback as to what works and what does not.

fields.title: Aria Jafari
fields.statement: I am running because I think that there will be big changes in the medical school soon that will impact our student experience. With a new building and a new clinical grading policy, we need someone who will advocate for policies that put students first. I’ve spent some time this year working with the administration to implement student feedback in the admissions process. I think I can be the person who stands up for students on a variety of important issues. I feel comfortable and confident in taking on big challenges and I am more motivated than ever to make these years together ones we will remember.

fields.title: Movimiento Estudiantil Chicano de Aztlan (MEChA)
fields.statement: MEChA de Stanford is part of a nationwide network of Chicano/Latino student organizations in colleges, universities, and high schools which works towards progressive changes in the Chicano/Latino community. Our organization strongly believes that a fair and adequate education is a right, not a privilege. Education, we believe, is the key to improving the social and political situation of the Chicano/Latino community. Our commitment to these beliefs is exemplified through our efforts and is translated into reality through the many programs that we sponsor and actions we undertake.

fields.title: ASSU Speakers Bureau
fields.statement:
The Stanford Speakers Bureau is a student-run organization that brings well-known speakers to campus. Special fees ensure that all of our events are free to Stanford students. This spring we will be bringing Hasidic Jewish reggae musician **Matisyahu** to campus, as well as other speakers we are in the process of confirming.

Over the past few years, special fees have enabled us to bring numerous speakers to campus, including:
 
•	**Adam Savage**, co-host of Discovery Channel's Mythbusters (2010)  
•	**Senator Joe Lieberman**, U.S. Senator from Connecticut (2009)  
•	**Pervez Musharraf**, former President of Pakistan (2009)  
•	**B.J. Novak**, producer, writer, and Ryan the Temp on NBC’s The Office (2009)  
•	**Jan Eliasson**, former UN President and Special Envoy to Darfur (2009)  
•	**David Mamet**, American author, essayist, playwright, screenwriter, and film director (2009)  
•	**Michael Uslan**, originator of the Batman movies (2009)  
•	**Madeline Albright**, former U.S. Secretary of State (2008)  
•	**Dave Barry**, comedy author and Pulitzer Prize winning Miami Herald columnist (2008)  
•	**Salman Rushdie**, renowned Indian-British author (2008)  

We also lend significant financial and publicity support to other campus organizations. Because of special fees, we have been able to help the following groups bring speakers to Stanford this year: 

•	Akwaaba Ghanaian Students Association  
•	Alpha Kappa Delta Phi  
•	Association of Chinese Students and Scholars  
•	ASSU Executives  
•	Atheists, Humanists and Agnostics  
•	Black Men's Forum  
•	Catholic Community at Stanford  
•	Coastal Society  
•	Comedy Club  
•	Jewish Student Association  
•	LGBT QuAD  
•	Pakistanis at Stanford  
•	Phi Beta Sigma  
•	Reformed University of Fellowship  
•	Society for International Affairs  
•	Spicmacay  
•	Stanford Africa Business Forum  
•	Stanford African Students Association  
•	Stanford African Student's Association  
•	Stanford Association for International Development  
•	Stanford Beyond Bars  
•	Stanford Ethipian and Eritrean Students Associations  
•	Stanford Immigration Rights Project  
•	Stanford Pre-Business Association  
•	Stanford Spoken Word  
•	Stanford Student Biodesign and Biopharma  
•	Stanford Students for Life  
•	Students for an Open Society  
•	Taiwanese Cultural Society  
•	Vegetarian Students for Conscious Living  

**Please vote YES for Speakers Bureau special fees so we can continue to bring well-known speakers to campus and support the dozens of student groups that rely on us each year.**

For more information, please visit our [website](http://speakers.stanford.edu). We value your input and welcome students to post their speaker suggestions to our [Facebook page](http://www.facebook.com/group.php?v=app_2344061033&gid=2200237390#!/group.php?v=wall&gid=2200237390) or e-mail us at speakers-bureau@assu.stanford.edu.

Stanford National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
fields.statement: As the 2009 California Youth & College Chapter of the Year and the 2007 recipient of the Dean's Award for Outstanding Student Organization, the Stanford NAACP has had a short but profound history of bringing local and national issues of political, educational, social and economic equality of rights and racial prejudice to the forefront of campus consciousness. We've prided ourselves with partnering with VSOs that cover the spectrum of student experience on campus, and have used our resources to bring some of the most influential leaders in the country to share their perspective on social justice, including CNN contributer Donna Brazile, public scholar Michael Eric Dyson and most recently top Senior Advisor to the President Valerie Jarrett. Off-campus, we've partnered with the SF 49er's Academy, EPA College Prep and the Palo Alto Police Department, creating workshops in police brutality and civil rights history, as well as tutoring programs for youth in East Palo Alto and voter canvassing and registration drives for older community members. With this combination of on-campus programming and off-campus initiatives our aim is always to open the door for insight and compassion, understanding and advocacy. Please help us continue to make an impact where it counts by voting in support of our Special Fees campaign.

KZSU 90.1 FM
fields.statement:
KZSU is Stanford's noncommercial, nonprofit radio station broadcasting at 90.1 FM.  

KZSU's staff is all volunteer, made up of assorted locals as well as Stanford students and staff. 

Besides DJs' music shows, KZSU has a live music show, public affairs programming (including public service announcements), live broadcasts of important Stanford events, the weekly Palo Alto City Council (Monday nights), and other specials. During the regular school year, there are live broadcasts of Stanford sporting events.

fields.title: Cardinal Free Clinics
fields.statement:
**Arbor Free Clinic and Pacific Free Clinic** are Stanford University student-run health clinics that provide free health care services to low-income, uninsured adults in Menlo Park and east San Jose.

Every dollar of Special Fees funding will go to expanding educational opportunities for CFC student volunteers. In the past year alone, more than **300 Stanford undergrad, medical, and grad students** have benefited from CFC's hands-on clinical training programs and from direct instruction by world-class Stanford physicians. CFC also helped to organize the **H1N1 vaccination campaign** for the Stanford community. Please help CFC continue to educate future leaders in medicine and public health by voting for us on the Special Fees ballot.

fields.title: Six Degrees: A Stanford Journal of Human Rights
fields.statement: Mission Statement: The separation that exists between Stanford and the rest of the world seems far greater than six degrees. But our connection to the world is real. This publication is committed to providing an arena for Stanford students to create awareness of human rights issues across the globe based on their personal experience and inspiration.

fields.title: Queer/Straight Alliance
fields.statement: The Queer/Straight Alliance (QSA) is a coalition of queer, questioning and allied students dedicated to creating open social spaces on campus and encouraging political activism for the achievement of queer rights.

fields.budget_summary:
Financial disclosure

Alternative Spring Break (ASB) only holds banking accounts with ASSU/SSE. ASB does not have any other bank accounts. ASB does not receive any funding from sources other than ASSU Special Fees. ASB does not receive funding from alumni, corporations, the University, or an endowment. ASB collects modest participant fees, which are subsidized or waived for financial aid students. This year, the majority of participants and a disproportionally high fraction of air travel students qualified for financial aid. ASB does not have any capital assets or equipment.

fields.title: Rachel Sussman
fields.statement: Hi everyone!  I've just finished the preclinical curriculum and am taking a year off to take care of my daughter, expected in mid-July--and to keep doing CCAP!  I served as one of the preclinical CCAP representatives this past year, and Amanda and I did our best to build a productive relationship with the Office of Medical Education faculty and staff.  Several projects that we instigated on behalf of input from students are ongoing, including reform of Q1a and pre-HHD curriculum, efforts to improve the quality and quantity of teaching evaluations, and attempts to provide better structure and guidelines for   the syllabi and powerpoint presentations used in required classes.  Aside from having a newborn to care for (!), I should have plenty of time to continue working on these projects and to start some new ones this coming year.  In the position of MD+ CCAP representative, I hope to ease the transition for the incoming preclinical CCAP representatives, and to serve as an extra bridge for communication between clinical students and CCAP, since the fact is that our clinical representatives are often extremely pressed for time.

fields.title: Julia Pederson
fields.statement:
I'm running to be your CCAP rep based upon my positive experience working with CCAP with respect to SWEAT and mini quarter improvements. Amanda and Rachel did an excellent job advocating on our behalf this year and I'll continue their use of focused curriculum lunches and informed, deliberate representation at monthly CCAP meetings with administration. Just as Amanda and Rachel were an excellent team, I think Erick, Jake and I can do a great job together representing preclinical students.  

In addition to advocating for improvements to HHD and the sometimes chaotic first year curriculum, I want to be part of the bigger conversation surrounding medical education. Medicine is changing fast, but the structure of medical education hasn't changed much since the Flexnor Report of 1910. Our administration realizes that, and will be looking to revamp the preclinical curriculum in the coming years. I hope to bring all of us into this conversation by seeking your input and pushing administration on questions such as, what skills are most vital in physician training? How can we better prepare ourselves for the leadership, teamwork, and communication required of an excellent physician? How could we use technology and innovative curriculum to improve how we learn and what we learn? What can Stanford do differently to truly prepare us to be future leaders of our profession? These are questions I want to help tackle as part of the CCAP and SMSA team.

I'd appreciate your support in this adventure and look forward to your ideas. -Julia

fields.title: Stephanie Carr
fields.statement: I'm excited for this opportunity to get more involved in SMSA!!  I plan to put a strong effort towards the secretarial duties and make a positive impact on our community.

fields.title: Erick Westbroek
fields.statement:
My decision to run to become your CCAP rep for the coming year was based on the productive interactions I have already had with CCAP. With Julia, I was able to change the minds of several CCAP members about SWEAT and mini quarter scheduling. These alterations will make the transition to medical school much more relaxed and, I feel, much more meaningful for next year’s class than the transition was for us.

Now having this working relationship with CCAP members, I hope to be able to advocate for improvement in our curriculum. My focus is two-fold. One goal is to push for changes that make the academic experience here at Stanford Med more manageable for students. This includes improving HHD, integrating first and second quarter POM more fully, and streamlining first year scheduling. My second goal is ensure that our curriculum is tuned to make us the best physicians we can be. To do this, I plan to identify those topics, skills, and techniques that we feel are over- or underrepresented in our current curriculum, and then work with CCAP in more appropriately assigning our precious training time.

To achieve these goals, I plan to continue the tradition of student outreach. Through continued curriculum lunches and informal interactions with the class, I will work with you to come up with a targeted agenda for each CCAP meeting that represents the desires of our class. Thank you for taking the time to consider each candidate. If you have any questions or ideas, please feel free to contact me. -Erick

fields.title: Ze Yuan
fields.statement:
**About myself**

My name is Ze Yuan, first-year PhD candidate in Electrical Engineering Department with an emphasis on transistor design. I did my undergraduate study at Tsinghua University in my hometown Beijing China, and I have been to the University of Hong Kong as an exchange student. During my undergraduate study, I served leading roles in many student associations, with the involvement in students' rights and extracurricular academic activities etc. I'm currently a broad member of Association of Chinese Scholar and Students at Stanford. For the past two quarters, while enjoying all kinds of convenience brought by the graduate community, I got this passion to work with GSC, to make more people enjoy their lives the way I do. Coming to Stanford I am not only new to the campus but also new to the country. Frankly speaking, like many of my peer PhD students in engineering and science fields, especially new international students, I don't think we have enough exposure to the whole campus life. It won't be hard to notice as long as you spend some time compare the profiles of all the candidates. However, to me, what is also apparent that new international students and PhD students have the willingness to make our voices heard, to take the initiative and get involved. The question is whether or not someone who could appreciate their concerns and willing to make effort to build better environment for this particular community with a fresh mind. That is why I am going for the candidacy to represent At-Large District in the GSC.

**My Goals:**

1 In addition to represent the interests of the whole graduate population, particularly I will bring the voices from new international students to guarantee their rights and obligation in health-care, campus resources and other relevant aspects.

2 Help balance the funding between different groups, to promote cross-culture events that could help the diversity and improve the involvement of graduate community, e.g. more welcome events on graduate community level for newly-arrived student in the fall quarter.

3 Categorize the current GSC activities and work on marketing and publishing to make sure the impacts reach out for the largest population possible.

fields.title: Deepa Galaiya
fields.statement:
I have had a rich, full Stanford experience in the last two years and would love to contribute to this community in a way that promotes the same for current and future students. I have seen and been inspired by the hard work that SMSA does in advocating for students, serving as an intermediary between the administration and the student body, connecting the medical school to the wider university community, and promoting inter-class unity. I truly commend this group of students for their commitment to making Stanford a better school and would like to add my efforts to theirs. 

I have become specifically interested in SMSA through the CBEI and implementation of clinical grades in the next few months. I would like to promote student involvement in ensuring that the process to test, evaluate, and continually change this new policy is transparent and fair. Beyond this issue, I would also like to be involved with: (1) improvements to the preclinical curriculum, (2) our transition into the LKSC, (3) the development of stronger near-peer mentorship and teaching opportunities, specifically between clinical and preclinical students, (4)better dissemination of research opportunities, (5) more intuitive and centralized funding applications for student groups, (6) the promotion of class and school-wide unity beyond the first year of medical school, (7) the creation of stronger ties, both curricular and social, to other graduate and professional schools, (8) and the foundation of relationships with other California medical schools to promote our involvement in issues about national and state health reform, reforms to medical education, and social events.

I have had experience running and helping to run a few other student organizations at Stanford, including AMSA, WAM, AMA, and SIGN. As part of these organizations, we introduced a book sale between clinical and preclinical students in September and in May (AMSA), organized an annual mixer with UCSF (AMSA), created a mentorship program between students and prominent female faculty (WAM), etc.

I'm particularly excited about working with the group of students who are running for SMSA this year. They are a capable and committed group, and I am eager to see what initiatives they will introduce. I will be doing research full time next year and feel that I can contribute to this group in a meaningful way.

fields.title: Mariko Howe
fields.statement:
Hello soon-to-be 4th years (aka my esteemed classmates). After a year away from SMSA, I think it's time to get back in the saddle. Also, I miss seeing your beautiful faces and want to have an excuse to make you contact me during the upcoming year for things like match and graduation. Mwah mwah I love you. Oh, and I promise to throw good parties. 

And on another note, I promise not to let David Craig do (most of) his crazy ideas. Except the good ones.

fields.title: Vicki Parikh
fields.statement:
Hi All! I'm really excited to be back at Stanford and am ready to celebrate our 5th+ years like med-student rockstars. I'm running for the position of class rep for two reasons: one, I think next year is going to represent some huge changes for the student body and two, I want to make our last year(s) at Stanford truly memorable. With respect to the coming changes: I know the implementation of the new evaluation system is going to effect not only those students being "graded" but also the rest of us, as the student environment on the wards may undergo some changes. I look forward to being a liaison between our class (which will have experienced the wards with and without this evaluation system) and the administration. I think our opinions and experience will be invaluable to them as they move forward with this new system. Also **incredibly** important is going to be our social experience during our last year of medical school, especially surrounding the match and graduation. I can't wait to be involved in celebrating the culmination of our hard work (and play) at Stanford Med with awesome events ranging from BBQs when the weather's nice (oh wait, that's all the time...), to the match day brunch, to trips to the city on switch weekends. And we won't forget about those of you in the lab, either -- we'll get you away from those gels and out of the tissue culture room, too! This is our last year before our friends who graduated "on time" (what a silly concept) scut us out as interns. Let's enjoy it!

PS -- I realize this is way too long. Thanks for making it to the end. :)

fields.title: Woody Chang
fields.statement:
I will be running to be your Pre-Clinical Policy and Advocacy Chair for the 2010-2011 year. I would like to continue to excellent work that this year's CCAP representatives and the current policy chairs have advocated and have done, as they were instrumental in revamping parts of Q1 to be more manageable for students among the other changes that have been made to make the curriculum a little less stressful for students.

I will always be able to lend an ear to any compliments or complaints that the student body has about the joys and stresses of all of the foibles of our current policies. My main goal is to ensure that the school continues to enact and enforce policies that not only advance our medical education, but also advocating for those policies changes, whether curricular, research, or otherwise, that allows us to pursue our interests and gives us the full experience of being in medicine while reducing the burdens on our already stressful lives and limited time. I look forward to acting as a liaison and advocate for the students as well as help bring forth other changes that you feel are necessary, whether they be scheduling issues or pushing changes that will help us learn the material better, or whether they are policy changes that ease the transition from pre-clinical to clinical.

I hope that I can continue to serve the student body in SMSA for the next academic year and thank you for your support.

Although I was on the other side of the finances (asking for money and overseeing its use), I learned a lot about the paperwork and bureaucracy behind attaining funding. I look forward to being an advocate for all of the student groups, classes, and events.

fields.title: Jessica Telleria
fields.statement:
Hello everybody!

I would like to be your 5+ representative for 3 reasons: 1) to serve as conduit of communication, advice and mentorship between clinical and preclinical students, 2) to act as a student voice regarding the upcoming changes in the curriculum, medical scholars, TMR, etc, and 3) to make the next year of medical school truly memorable, whether you are graduating or not. 

I enjoy organizing social events around athletic events, major or not so major holidays and post-stressful-med-school events (ie boards, end of quarter exams, switch weekends). My recent event planning, for example, includes 90s Hip Hop dance night in SF, Final-4 basketball party at a local pub, movie night, Tahoe skiing, etc. Plus, as I am returning from a research year, I have had ample time to explore the diverse activities the bay area has to offer. And trust me, I have explored, haha! 

Regarding my other objectives, I think it is very important to have frequent and effective communication between classes, especially in regards to clerkships. From day one I have always made a major effort to talk to those who have gone before me, because of that I have felt amply prepared for the transition to clerkships, how to shine on the wards, how to plan your final year and sub-internships, etc. I have a strong desire and moral obligation to pass on what I have learned to the next group as there is no reason students should not benefit from the experiences of others. Finally, in response to the upcoming changes in the medical school I will continually strive to voice your concerns and ensure they are heard at the administrative level. I personally feel the student perspective is essential to shaping the future of Stanford Medicine and continuing the traditions and culture of our student body. 

Thank you for your consideration and I wish you the best of luck next year!

Jess

fields.title: Yichuan Ding
fields.statement:
I had my B.S. in Zhejiang University, mainland of China, and my Master degree in University of Waterloo. Now I am in my 3rd year of PhD in MS&E. 

After I came to Stanford, I realized the student life at Stanford is particularly funny! I enjoyed a lot of student activities, organized by GSC or ACSSS (Association of Stanford Chinese Students and Scholars). In my second year, I became the VP of ACSSS for social activities, which broadened my vision and enlarged my social network. More importantly, I enjoyed the pleasure of team-work with my buddies, and making efforts to promote the quality of social life for Stanford Chinese students.Now I am enthusiastic to make my efforts to a larger scale: the Stanford students.  

I have participated many activities by GSC, like new student BBQ, grad formal. I feel that GSC really did a lot to support student activities and it greatly promotes the life quality of Stanford students. I feel GSC is a nice organization and it might be a good way to contribute my effort to Stanford community by joining GSC
